On January 21 2020, police arrested 43 people in Eastleigh and detained them for two days on suspicion of several offenses related to ""terrorism"".
On January 21 2020, an angry mob beat a man who had been pretending to be deaf to solicit money in Migori. [size=no report]
On January 23 2020, unidentified assailants clashed with police between Liboi and Dadaab in Garissa County. 1 police officer was injured.
On January 24 2020, youth armed with stones and clubs blocked members of parliament allied to Deputy President William Ruto from giving a press conference in Mombasa. [size=no report]
On January 24 2020, suspected Al Shabaab militants attacked a passenger bus traveling toward Wajir, injuring 2 people.
On January 26 2020, residents protested in Garissa over recent attacks against civilians. [size=no report]
On January 27 2020, a police officer was killed by unidentified assailants related to inter-clan clashes in Trans Mara, Narok.
On January 27 2020, the Siria and Uasin Gushi clans clashed in Trans Mara, leaving 70 people displaced.
On January 27 2020, Pokot militants attacked Turkanas working in construction near Lomelo in Kapedo. 1 police officer was killed in the attack, along with 2 others. 14 others were injured.
On January 28 2020, protesters mounted banners along major highways in Nairobi to demand an end to corruption in the judicial system. [size=no report]
On January 29 2020, a mob stoned to death a man who was accused of stealing a chicken in Kisenye, Homa Bay. [size=no report]
On January 30 2020, legislators marched in Kiambu to demand a judge complete the swearing in of the Kiambu governor. [size=no report]
On January 31 2020, a mob evicted the Homa Bay hospital's new administrator from office over claims of incompetence. [size=no report]
On February 7 2020, suspected Al Shabaab militants killed a man in Ijara, Garissa county.

On February 7 2020, residents clashed with police in Ganze, Kilifi county, over the death of a pregnant girl at the Bamba police station. 10 people were arrested and several people were injured. [size=no report]
Around February 8 2020, Al Shabaab claims it attacked the Hulugho police station in Garissa County. 3 police officers were wounded.
On February 9 2020, Al Shabaab clashed with police in Milihoi, Lamu. They burnt two construction vehicles. No casualties were reported.
On February 11 2020, Al Shabaab militants clashed with police in Bula Golol, Fafi. 1 police officer was killed.
On February 11 2020, a mob killed a man in Maragwa, Murang'a, after an alleged attempted rape. [size=no report]
On February 12 2020, Al Shabaab militant attacked Sangailu in Garissa county.
On February 15 2020, an angry mob stoned to death a murder suspect in Matuu market, Machakos. [size=no report]
On February 16 2020, traders who supplied goods to the Kenya Prisons Service protested in Nairobi over missing payments. [size=no report]
On February 17 2020, a mob stoned to death a suspected thief in Matuu (Yatta, Machakos). [size=no report]
On February 17 2020, a mob beat up a man in Sindo (Kaksingri West, Suba South, Homa Bay) who was alleged to have raped a woman. Police forces intervened. [size=no report]
On February 19 2020, over 100 residents of the Mount Elgon constituency marched in Bungoma (Khalaba, Kanduyi, Bungoma) to demand action regarding a rise in donkey theft. [size=over 100]
Around 19 February 2020 (week of), suspected Pokot militia attacked Ngaratuko village near Bartabwa (Baringo North, Baringo) and injured a young boy before stealing a number of animals.
On February 19 2020, unidentified assailants destroyed a church in Mbale Town (Wundanyi/Mbale, Taita Taveta) related to a land dispute.
On February 19 2020, suspected Al Shabaab militants attacked a public transportation bus in Sarman (Bute, Wajir Central, Wajir), killing 3 people.

Around 20 February 2020 (as reported), an IED exploded targeting a bus carrying Christians along the Nairobi-Mandera road (Mandera East, Mandera), killing four and injuring several others. Al Shabaab claimed responsibility.
On February 20 2020, at least 200 contractors demonstrated in Mbale (Lugaga-Wamuluma, Vihiga) over unresolved debts. [size=at least 200]
On February 20 2020, suspected Al Shabaab militants set fire to the home of a Kenyan police reservist in Sangailu (Bura, Fafi, Garissa).
On 21 February 2020, alleged bandits attacked and killed three National Police Reservists from the Tugen ethnic group near Chemorongion (Baringo South, Baringo) during cattle raids.
On February 23 2020, Al Shabaab militants attacked Qorisa (coded as Ijara) and burnt down four houses belonging to police reservists.
On February 24 2020, at least 50 youths destroyed property on a private farm in Mai Mahiu (Naivasha, Nakuru) related to a land dispute.
On February 25 2020, clashes broke out between two groups of people in Arbeqarmso (coded as Wajir) over a land dispute. 1 person was killed and 18 others injured.
On February 25 2020, police clashed with prison suppliers in Nairobi, during a demonstration over delayed payments. [size=no report]
On February 25 2020, a mob killed a man in Mishomoroni (Kandzandani, Nyali, Mombasa) after he broke into a house and stole items. [size=no report]
On February 25 2020, a mob killed a man and burnt down buildings after the man killed another person during a bar fight in Nyando area (Kisumu). [size=no report]
On February 25 2020, residents protested over the poor state of roads between Homa Bay and Ndiwa (Homa Bay). [size=no report]
On February 26 2020, a mob killed three people in Mishomoroni (Kandzandani, Nyali, Mombasa) after they attacked people with pangas. [size=no report]
On February 26 2020, armed clashes broke out between residents and a group of at least 50 men hired by a private developer regarding a land dispute in Athi River (Mavoko, Machakos).

On February 26 2020, unidentified assailants attacked the Naibung'a conservancy near Mukogodo (Mugogodo West, Laikipia North, Laikipia). 2 police reservists and 2 attackers were killed and a school building was destroyed.
On February 27 2020, residents demonstrated in Chebunyo (Chepalungu, Bomet) against the county government's decision to stop the desilting of a major dam in the area. [size=no report]
On March 2 2020, over 200 hotel workers protested in Diani (Gombato Bongwe, Msambweni, Kwale) over salary demands. [size=over 200]

On 4 March 2020, a large group of youth from Siaya district (armed with machetes) attacked Shibina village in Mumias West constituency (Kakamega district), prompting fighting with youth from the village, resulting in two deaths (one from each side). The cause of the clash is said to be related to cattle rustling in the area.
On March 5 2020, hundreds of residents protested at the Mokowe water office in Mokowe (Lamu West, Lamu) over a lack of water. [size=hundreds]
On March 5 2020, police used tear gas to disrupt traders protesting in Eldoret (Kapsoya, Ainabkoi, Uasin Gishu) against extortion by police. [size=no report]

On 6 March 2020, students demonstrated against poor conditions at a college in Bungoma town (Bungoma district). Police fired tear gas into dwellings, and were filmed beating students who appeared to have been forced to lie on the ground. [size=no report]

On 7 March 2020, students killed a security guard with blunt objects at the Uriri Vocational Training Center in Migori (Suna West, Migori) after the security guard had early attacked a group of students, accusing them of dismounting security bulbs. No arrests were made. [size=no report]

On 9 March 2020, students burnt and looted shops, and barricaded roads with bonfires in Makutano (Kapenguria, West Pokot), over the mugging and murder of a student on the previous day. [size=no report]

On 9 March 2020, University of Nairobi (UoN) students set alight the university custodian's office in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) and clashed with riot police. The demonstration followed after the death of a student who was kidnapped and killed. [size=no report]

On 10 March 2020, lawyers marched in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega), following the killing of a colleague. The demonstrators accused police of being responsible for the surge in insecurity in the county. [size=no report]
On or around 11 March 2020, police escaped unharmed when they were targeted with an explosive by Al Shabaab militants in Jabibar on the road between Bambo and Rhamu town (Mandera North, Mandera).
On 11 March 2020, two people were killed in a suspected Al-Shabaab attack on the town of Mandera (Mandera East, Mandera).
On 11 March 2020, a man was abducted by suspected Al-Shabaab members when the group ambushed a bus headed to Mandera (Mandera East, Mandera) from Nairobi. No casualties reported.
On 12 March 2020, traders demonstrated in Embu town (Manyatta, Embu), demanding compensation from the governor after unknown assailants set the Marigiti market alight. [size=no report]
On 13 March 2020, two police officers were killed when their vehicle hit an IED in Garissa (Dujis, Garissa). It is suspected that the IED was planted by Al Shabaab militants.

column6: Military Forces of Kenya (2013-) Special Forces
column17: On 13 March 2020, Kenyan special forces killed six suspected Al-Shabaab militants and captured one in the Jirole area in Garissa (Dujis, Garissa).
On 13 March 2020, Ethiopian soldiers crossed the border and killed five people in Sessi, Moyale town (Moyale, Marsabit). The victims were accused of harbouring Ethiopian rebels.

On 15 March 2020, members of an unidentified armed group targeted an ambulance with an IED and opened fire on the ambulance after the IED detonated in Hulugho (Hulugho, Ijara, Garissa), leaving 3 dead.
On 15 March 2020, two policemen were killed in an IED explosion by an unidentified group as they drove to the scene of another attack on an ambulance in Hulugho (Hulugho, Ijara, Garissa).

column6: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) Border Patrol Unit
column17: On 17 March 2020, Border Patrol Units used tear gas to disperse a crowd of civilians in Bungoma (Khalaba, Kanduyi, Bungoma). The civilians had gathered to receive hand sanitizers brought to them by a local politician, while the police dispersed the crowd in order to prevent transmission of coronavirus.
On 17 March 2020, a mob killed a civilian whom they suspected of having coronavirus in Ukunda (Gombato, Msambweni, Kwale). [size=no report]
On or before 19 March 2020, Kenyan Military Forces killed 12 Al Shabaab militants in Boni National Reserve (Ijara, Ijara, Garissa).

On 21 March 2020, traders protested after the Kenyan government decided to charge an access fee to the stadium they were forcibly relocated to in Kisumu (Market Milimani, Kisumu Central, Kisumu). The traders were forcibly relocated as part of a greater effort to prevent the spread of coronavirus. [size=no report]
On March 21 2020, Kenyan military forces clashed with Al Shabaab militants in Milihoi (Mkunumbi, Lamu West, Lamu). No casualties were reported.

On or around 25 March 2020, about 10 boda boda drivers were arrested after fatally stabbing a young boda boda driver in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) for breaking the national coronavirus curfew. [size=about 10]

column8: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) General Service Unit
column17: On March 26 2020, hundreds of commuters threw stones at general service unit police officers who were trying to implement a coronavirus social distancing order at the Likoni Channel ferry crossing (Mombasa). Several people were injured in a stampede. [size=hundreds]
On 26 March 2020, police used teargas to disperse a crowd at the Muringene and Laare markets in Meru (North Imenti, Meru), during the enforcement of coronavirus social distancing.
On 27 March 2020, police officers beat a delivery driver along with other motorists with batons in Nakuru (Nakuru Town East, Nakuru) during the nationwide coronavirus curfew.
On 27 March 2020, a boda boda driver was fatally wounded by police near the Kosele trading centre in Rachuonyo (Kasipul, Homa Bay) during the enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew.

On 27 March 2020, police were accused of beating motorists and pedestrians in the Nyanza administrative area near Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) during the implementation of the national coronavirus curfew.
On 27 March 2020, police were accused of beating and using teargas on civilians in Kondele (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) during the national coronavirus curfew. A boda boda driver was severely assaulted.
On 27 March 2020, at least five people were reportedly injured by police in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) during the national coronavirus curfew.

column16: HRW; Nairobi News; New York Times; Washington Post
column17: On 27 March 2020, police was accused of kicking and beating hundreds of commuters at a ferry with batons, forced them to lie down and threw teargas canisters at the crowd who attempted to return home before the national coronavirus curfew implementation in Likoni (Likoni, Mombasa). Dozens of people were injured, including a journalist. A boda boda driver died from his injuries after police officers assaulted him following the start of coronavirus curfew.
On 27 March 2020, the government implemented a national coronavirus curfew in Kenya.

On 27 March 2020, a land activist was fatally shot by a police officer in Kanamai in Majengo (Vihiga). The activist was attempting to block a developer from erecting a perimeter wall on a quarter an acre piece of land. A Kilifi Social Justice Centre Rapid Response officer said the activist could have been targeted because he was a key witness in a forced disappearance case.
On March 28 2020, police used teargas to disperse residents in Nyamasaria (Kisumu East, Kisumu) defying a curfew order to curb the spread of coronavirus.
On March 28 2020, police clashed with residents in Kondele (Market Milimani, Kisumu Central, Kisumu) defying a curfew order to curb the spread of coronavirus. [size=no report]
On 28 March 2020, police reportedly assaulted people in a block of six units in the Kayole neighborhood, Matopeni area in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) during the coronavirus curfew.

On 28 March 2020, three police officers whipped women during the enforcement of coronavirus social distancing at the Mitunguu market in Imenti South (Central Imenti, Meru). A journalist who captured the event was also assaulted after refusing to delete the footage of the assaults.
Around 29 March 2020 (week of), a man succumbed from his injuries after being assaulted by police in Dandora (Embakasi North, Nairobi).
On 29 March 2020, a boda boda driver was reportedly seriously injured after police assaulted him in a village near Busia (Matayos, Busia).
On 29 March 2020, a boda boda driver was fatally assaulted by police in Homabay (Homa Bay), during the national coronavirus lockdown.
Around 30 March 2020 (week of), a man succumbed from his injuries after police assaulted him in Nakuru (Nakuru Town East, Nakuru).
Around 30 March 2020 (week of), residents demonstrated in Nakuru (Nakuru Town East, Nakuru) after a man was fatally assaulted by police. Police claimed it was a mob-related attack. [size=no report]
On 30 March 2020, police shot a female trader with live ammunition in Mumias (Mumias West, Kakamega) during the coronavirus curfew.

column16: Daily Nation (Kenya); France24; New York Times
column17: On 30 March 2020, a young boy was fatally wounded in Huruma, Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) when police used live ammunition during the enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew.
On 1 April 2020, police officers allegedly broke the limbs of civilians in Mauche (Njoro, Nakuru) when enforcing the national coronavirus curfew.
On or around 1 April 2020, police officers allegedly broke the limbs of civilians in Nakuru (Njoro, Nakuru) when enforcing the national coronavirus curfew.
On 1 April 2020, a few shoppers were reportedly assaulted by police in Kipevu (Changamwe, Mombasa) with whips and batons during the coronavirus curfew.

On 1 April 2020, a man succumbed from his injuries after being allegedly beaten up by police in Ukunda (Msambweni, Kwale) during enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew. Police had also used teargas to disperse at least 12 people, including the deceased, at a bar.
On or around 1 April 2020, a man succumbed from his injuries after being allegedly beaten up by police in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) during enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew.
On 2 April 2020, armed Tugen youth raided Ngiyang near Kolowa (Tiaty, Baringo), injuring a Pokot herder and stealing 60 goats.

On 2 April 2020, tens of supporters of Kirinyaga County deputy governor and member of the Jubilee Party, wielding rungus and whips, stormed a meeting of Kirinyaga governor in Defatha Village near Kutus (Mwea, Kirinyaga), demanding that the governor not address journalists. [size=tens]
On 2 April 2020, police reportedly assaulted a man inside his compound in Mwangulu area in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) during the coronavirus curfew.

On 2 April 2020, miraa traders barricaded the Isiolo-Moyale highway in Isiolo town (Isiolo North, Isiolo) with burning tyres and boulders in demonstration over the demolition of their kiosks. A ban has been placed on the sale and transportation of miraa during the national coronavirus curfew. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]
On 2 April 2020, a man was allegedly assaulted by police officers in Mumias (Mumias West, Kakamega), during enforcement of the ongoing national coronavirus curfew.

On 2 April 2020, at least 10 boda boda drivers fatally stabbed two boda boda drivers and injured five others in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) for allegedly carrying more than one pillion passenger during the national coronavirus curfew. The transport of more than one passenger had earlier been outlawed by the government. [size=about 10]
On or around 2 April 2020, a police officer raped a women who had been arrested for theft inside his house on the Matuu police station base (Yatta, Machakos).

On 3 April 2020, boda boda drivers associated with the Community-Based Organisation (CBO) and members of the Shule gang along with bobda boda drivers not associated with the CBO clashed in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) over CBO law enforcement methods. Four fatalities were reported. [size=at least four]

On 3 April 2020, a woman was allegedly shot and injured by police when they opened fire to disperse a crowd at a market in Mumias (Mumias West, Kakamega) during enforcement of the ongoing national coronavirus curfew.
On 3 April 2020, one person was fatally shot when Isiria and Erwasingishu clans from the Masaai ethnic group clashed in Transmara (Narok South, Narok) over livestock theft. Police intervened.

On 3 April 2020, a 13 year old was hospitalised with fractures on his right leg after he was allegedly assaulted with clubs and gun butts by police officers in Busia town (Matayos, Busia) during the enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew.

On or around 4 April 2020, residents threw teargas canisters back at police in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega). The police deployed the cannisters during enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew. [size=no report]
On 4 April 2020, a trader was fatally assaulted by police in Kawangware (Kilimani, Nairobi) during the national coronavirus curfew.

On 4 April 2020, villagers demonstrated in Nyahera in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) when police tried to remove a body of a young girl who was killed in a suspected ritual killing. Demonstrators demanded that police get to the bottom of the killing of girls in the area. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]

On or around 5 April 2020, villagers gathered at a farm in Kajiado (Kajiado Central, Kajiado), armed with sticks and rungus, and demanded that workers who arrived during the night leave due to coronavirus outbreak fears. [size=no report]
On 7 April 2020, 10 houses were set alight during inter-clan clashes between two Maasai ethnic militias in Pimbinyiet (Narok South, Narok).

On 7 April 2020, a trader was killed during a police operation in Mumias (Mumias West, Kakamega) after police used teargas to disperse a crowd during the national coronavirus curfew. Police are accused of beating traders.
On 10 April 2020, a man was fatally assaulted by police in Ruai (Kasarani, Nairobi), within the context of coronavirus measures.

On or around 10 April 2020, gold miners confronted foreign gold mine investors at a market in Migori County and then followed the group to the mine, accusing investors of land grabbing. The mob looted gold-rich stones, vehicle parts, mining and drilling equipment. [size=no report]
On 12 April 2020, six suspected gang rape suspects were rescued by police from a mob who attempted to lynch them in Elburgon (Molo, Nakuru). [size=no report]
On 12 April 2020, police were pelted with stones, one seriously injured, while enforcing the national coronavirus curfew in Kitui (Kitui Central, Kitui). [size=no report]

On 13 April 2020, two suspected Al-Shabaab militants were killed and several police officers were injured during a gun battle in Wajir (Wajir East, Wajir). Number of casualties not confirmed by police.

On 13 April 2020, ten men, armed with crude weapons, stormed the house of a People Daily journalist in Tente, near Nyamira (West Mugirango, Nyamira). Neighbours alerted police, one suspect arrested after neighbours caught and assaulted him. Reports indicate the ambush was over a news story involving political figures.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), residents of Nchooro near Tigania (Tigania West, Meru) demonstrated, accusing the chief of bias during the allocation of relief to those in need during the coronavirus curfew. [size=no report]
Around 15 April 2020 (month of), a fire fight was reported in Qaqabey near Wajir (Wajir East, Wajir) between police and suspected al Shabaab members. At least 10 fatalities reported.

column6: Military Forces of Somalia (2017-) Jubaland Security Force
column17: On 22 April 2020, a shootout was reported between Jubaland troops and the Somali National Army (SNA) in Mandera Town (Mandera East, Mandera). No casualties reported.
On or around 24 April 2020, community members killed three men suspected of robberies in Vihiga (Vihiga). [size=no report]
On 24 April 2020, police killed a suspect accused of being part or a terror group in Likoni (Likoni, Mombasa) and seized several weapons.
On 24 April 2020, two police officers died in a bomb attack in Dabacity near El Wak (Mandera South, Mandera). Al Shabaab claimed responsibility.
On or around 24 April 2020, a Kenyan military base was attacked in Sheikh Barrow (Lafey, Mandera). Al Shabaab claimed responsibility. No casualties reported.

On 24 April 2020, local residents staged a demonstration and blocked a bus carrying passengers coming from a funeral from entering the village of Kalyet near Kabirer (Kipkelion West, Kericho), due to coronavirus fears. [size=no report]

On 25 April 2020, a woman was injured during a confrontation between Kenya Forest Service guards and community members armed with pangas and clubs in Handolo near Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega). The confrontation was over forest resource protection. [size=no report]
On 26 April 2020, Embu traders fatally assaulted a suspected robber with pangas in Embu (Manyatta, Embu). [size=no report]

On 27 April 2020, women demonstrated over the theft of their underwear in Murang'a (Kiharu, Murang'a). It is suspected that the theft was linked to the making of face masks during the coronavirus curfew. [size=no report]

On 27 April 2020, a man was killed during a confrontation between Kenya Forest Service guards and community members armed with pangas and clubs in Handolo near Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega). [size=no report]
On 27 April 2020, community members fatally lynched a man at Kipkener in the Marakwet area (Marakwet East, Elgeyo-Marakwet) after he confessed to killing his two sons. [size=no report]

On 27 April 2020, health workers demonstrated and forcibly attempted to breach a police roadblock in Thika (Thika Town, Kiambu), when police officers denied them entry into the town during the coronavirus curfew. The health workers had allegedly failed to show their job accreditations. [size=no report]

Around 1 May 2020 (week of), about 60 refugees held a sit in demonstration at the United Nations High Commission for Refugees-run camp in Kakuma (Turkana West, Turkana), demanding to be relocated due to insecurity. [size=about 60]
Around 3 May 2020 (week of), a police officer reportedly sexually assaulted a man, who he arrested, at the Nakuru Central Police Station (Nakuru Town East, Nakuru).
On 4 May 2020, a man was fatally assaulted by police in Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi), within the context of coronavirus measures.

On 4 May 2020, youth demonstrated in Kibera (Kibra, Nairobi) following the killing of a journalist in the area, demanding answers on where police were during the coronavirus curfew. Demonstrators took one of the suspects to the scene of the crime and killed him. [size=no report]

On 4 May 2020, about 500 residents of Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi) blocked police from taking the body of a man who was allegedly killed by police while enforcing the coronavirus curfew. The demonstrators then took the body to the police station, demanding justice. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=about 500]

Around 5 May 2020 (as reported), a KFS officer was attacked by a group of youth, armed with swords, over the eviction of squatters from Kirisia Forest near Maralal (Samburu West, Samburu). No fatalities reported.

On 6 May 2020, community members stoned two police officers and a man accused of terrorising the community in Kalwal village near Ndhiwa (Ndhiwa, Homa Bay). One police officer died. Community members accused the police officer of working with a man accused of assaulting a woman in the community with a machete. [size=no report]
Around 6 May 2020 (week of), police reportedly assaulted a man with whips and blunt objects at Silibwet trading centre near Bomet (Bomet East, Bomet) during the enforcement of the coronavirus curfew.
On 7 May 2020, hundreds of Eastleigh residents (Kamukunji, Nairobi) demonstrated following the implementation of a partial coronavirus lockdown in the area. [size=hundreds]

On 8 May 2020, hundreds of traders and community members lit tires and blocked the road near the Korogocho market (Ruaraka, Nairobi) after access to the market was closed off and structures were destroyed by contractors carrying out demolitions. Demonstrators damaged property next to the road. Police used teargas and water cannons to disperse the crowd. [size=hundreds]

Around 8 May 2020 (as reported), more than 30 community members in Kissi county (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) set alight 4 suspected gang members accused of cattle theft along the boundary between Bobasi and Kisii sub-counties. 4 fatalities reported. [size=more than 30]
Around 10 May 2020 (as reported), police reportedly assaulted a man at Keliot village in the area of Bomet township (Bomet East, Bomet) when enforcing the national coronavirus curfew.
On 11 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Eastleigh (Kamukunji, Nairobi), demanding mass testing and food relief during the coronavirus curfew. [size=no report]
On 12 May 2020, a mob stoned a 19-year-old teen to death for allegedly stealing a phone from a female hawker in the Komarock area in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi). [size=no report]
Around 12 May 2020 (as reported), a mob attempted to lynch a man accused of attempting to rob a woman in Eastleigh (Kamukunji, Nairobi). Police intervened. [size=no report]
On 12 May 2020, a mob fatally lynched a man accused of killing his girlfriend in Gem, Siaya (Alego Usonga, Siaya). [size=no report]
On 13 May 2020, suspected bandits clashed with police forces during an attack on Ngaratuko village near Bartabwa (Baringo North, Baringo) and injured a Tugen National Police Reservist.

On 13 May 2020, hundreds of Antu Ambui residents marched to the home of the chief in Igembe North, near Antubeiga (Igembe North, Meru), armed with rocks, sticks and the machetes. The demonstrators accused the chief of bias when allocating a state stipend meant for those most vulnerable to the effects of the coronavirus. Demonstrators destroyed a fence, two government motorcycles and miraa bushes. Police intervened. [size=hundreds]

On 13 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Ngurubani town, also known as Wanguru (Mwea, Kirinyaga), demanding the resignation of the governor, accusing her of the slow implementation of development projects and payment of health worker salaries. Police arrested 30 demonstrators. [size=at least 30]

On 14 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Eldoret (Ainabkoi, Uasin Gishu) after stray dogs attacked and killed a man. Following the demonstration, a group of youth went to kill 8 dogs. [size=no report]

On 15 May 2020, an unknown number of suspected al Shabaab militants attacked the Khorof Harar police post in Wajir East, near Qarsa (Wajir East, Wajir). The armed attackers raided the police post with motors and grenades and launched heavy gunfire. 7 police officers reportedly killed.
On 16 May 2020, KDF troops launched airstrikes, targeting Al-Shabaab militants in Wajir area (Wajir, Wajir East). Casualty figures are unknown (Coded as 0).

On 17 May 2020, the father of a Lamu senator was shot by police at the Doldol Police Station (Laikipia North, Laikipia) after police arrested him for failing to wear a face mask during the national coronavirus curfew. The man was severely injured.
On 18 May 2020, Al-Shabaab members shot at police officers along the Bura-East-Garissa Lappset road (Mwatate, Taita Taveta) after the police vehicle missed a planted IED. No fatalities reported.

Around 18 May 2020 (as reported), a heavy explosion hit a military vehicle carrying Kenyan police in an area between Harar and Fifty (Khorof Harar, Wajir East, Wajir). Seven police officers were injured.

Around 19 May 2020 (as reported), villagers of Lari (Lari, Kiambu) demonstrated after a newly opened dam in a nearby village flooded the village. The demonstrators accused residents of the nearby village of placing them in danger. [size=no report]
On 20 May 2020, a carpenter was assaulted and injured by police in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) for not wearing a mask during the national coronavirus curfew. He later succumbed from his injuries.

On 20 May 2020, a group of youth threw stones at police officers, injuring one officer, who were enforcing the national coronavirus curfew in Litein (Buret, Kericho). Police dispersed the crowd with live ammunition. One stray bullet injured an off duty paramedic who was hospitalised. [size=no report]

On 21 May 2020, truck drivers barricaded the Bungoma-Malaba highway (Kanduyi, Bungoma) leading to Uganda. The demonstrators accused Ugandan authorities of harassment and discrimination. They were demanding the release of a truck driver detained in Uganda due to testing positive for the coronavirus and the release of their tests taken a week before. [size=no report]
On 21 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Rongo (Rongo, Migori), accusing police of poor performance after a journalist was attacked with a heavy object by two unknown assailants. [size=no report]

On 22 May 2020, Ikoli and Nandi community militias, armed with arrows, clashed in Kakamega County (Kakamega, Lurambi, Kakamega). Villagers in Ikoli accused some Nandi villagers of trespassing into their grazing fields. Five injuries and one fatality reported.

Around 25 May 2020 (between 23 May - 27 May), Kipsigis and Maasai communities clashed in Ololbangi in Narok South Subcounty (Narok) and Olpusimoru in Narok North subcounty (Narok), respectively. Eight fatalities reported. Two confirmed in Oloruasi area, one confirmed on the Narok-Nakuru border. Several houses were torched. The clash was reportedly over livestock theft. Fatalities split between two events.

Around 25 May 2020 (between 23 May - 27 May), Kipsigis and Maasai communities clashed in Ololbangi in Narok South Subcounty (Narok) and Olpusimoru in Narok North subcounty (Narok), respectively. Eight fatalities reported. Two confirmed in Oloruasi area, one confirmed on the Narok-Nakuru border. Several houses were torched. The clash was reportedly over livestock theft. Fatalities split between two events.
On 26 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Ukwala (Ugenya, Siaya) over the delayed completion of a bridge. [size=no report]
Around 27 May 2020 (week of), suspected police officers severely assaulted a man with batons in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) during the national coronavirus curfew.

Around 29 May 2020 (as reported), about 3000 youth employed under the government National Hygiene Programme, created to help unemployed youth during the coronavirus pandemic, barricaded roads with rocks in Mukuru (Starehe, Nairobi) and pelted stones at police, demanding the payment of their salaries. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=about 3000]
Around 29 May 2020, two Kenya military officers and a police officers were injured during a clash with suspected al-Shabaab members in Garissa town (Dujis, Garissa).

On 29 May 2020, police fatally shot two people in Katanin Village near Kapsabet (Emgwen, Nandi). The IPOA are currently investigating several cases of police brutality in Kenya during the national coronavirus lockdown.

column16: Kenya Standard; AP; Citizen (Kenya); Daily Nation (Kenya)
column17: On 30 May 2020, police officers shot and killed a suspected al-Shabaab militant and two children he used as a shield in Diani (Msambweni, Kwale) after he threw a grenade at the police. The suspect's wife and three other children were also injured.

On 30 May 2020, police fatally shot three family members in Kwale (Matuga, Kwale). The IPOA are currently investigating several cases of police brutality in Kenya during the national coronavirus lockdown.

column16: Media Max Network; East African Standard
column17: On 31 May 2020, police shot dead 23 donkeys, set alight 20 houses and vandalized and looted shops in Riongo Village near Tiati (Tiaty, Baringo) during a disarmament exercise. No fatalities/injuries reported.
On 31 May 2020, a police officer sexually assaulted a woman he was interrogating at the Manyatta Police Station (Manyatta, Embu).

On 31 May 2020, police fatally shot a woman at a roadblock in Emali (Makueni). The IPOA are currently investigating several cases of police brutality in Kenya during the national coronavirus lockdown.

On 1 June 2020, police fatally shot a homeless man working at Marikiti market in Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi). The IPOA are currently investigating several cases of police brutality in Kenya during the national coronavirus lockdown.

On 2 June 2020, about 20 demonstrators gathered outside the US Embassy in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) to demonstrated over the death of an African-American man in Minneapolis police custody, in support of the Black Lives Matter movement, as well as police brutality and extrajudicial killings in Kenya. Police intervened. [size=about 20]
Around 2 June 2020 (as reported), about 300 people demonstrated in Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi) after police fatally shot a homeless man who works at Marikiti market. [size=about 300]
On 3 June 2020, women marched in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi), calling for peace ahead of the polls. [size=no report]
On 3 June 2020, residents demonstrated in Bomet (Bomet East, Bomet) after three people were attacked by people who pretended to be animals. [size=no report]

On 4 June 2020, residents barricaded the Kajiado-Namanga road in Kajiado (Kajiado Central, Kajiado) with burning tires, demanding the unconditional release of former Matapato North MCA. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]

On 6 June 2020, four people were reportedly killed in clashes between Borana and Degodia communities at Barderero, Moyale (Moyale, Marsabit). Conflicting reports suggested that there were 7 fatalities.

column16: Citizen (Kenya); Daily Nation (Kenya); Kenya Standard; Media Max Network
column17: On 7 June 2020, a woman, accused of breaking into the house of a police officer, was dragged behind a motorcycle by policemen in Olenguruone in Narok county (Narok North, Narok).

On 7 June 2020, a mob fatally assaulted a man and set his body alight in Marimanti (Tharaka, Tharaka-Nithi). The man was caught by the mob with the body of an elderly man he killed earlier. [size=no report]
On 7 June 2020, a man, suspected of theft, was hospitalised after being shot by police with live ammunition in Makutano (Kapenguria, West Pokot) during the national coronavirus curfew.
On 8 June 2020, a police officer was attacked and killed by three men, armed with pangas, knives and clubs, in Tchundwa village in Lamu East (Basuba, Lamu East, Lamu).

column9: Rendilles Ethnic Group (Kenya); Taxi Drivers (Kenya); Students (Kenya)
column17: On 8 June 2020, 4 people, including a student and motor bike operator, were killed in a suspected tribal attack in Songa (Saku, Marsabit). All victims were from the Rendilles ethnic group.
On 8 June 2020, around 200 people demonstrated in Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi) against police brutality since the imposed national coronavirus curfew. [size=around 200]
On 10 June 2020, herders clashed over a watering point in Gof-Choba near Sololo (Moyale, Marsabit). Three fatalities reported.
On 11 June 2020, nearly 700 people demonstrated in Kutus (Mwea, Kirinyaga) to urge the senate to uphold the impeachment of Kirinyaga County governor. [size=nearly 700]

Around 13 June 2020 (as reported), a funeral of a well-known artist was disrupted by a group of mourners in Kadiju village near Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu). Police used teargas to attempt to disperse the crowd who took the casket to the nearest mortuary for preservation. [size=no report]
On 13 June 2020, residents stoned a man accused of theft to death and set his body alight in Gatithini in Tharaka-North sub country (Marimanti, Tharaka, Tharaka-Nithi). [size=no report]
On 13 June 2020, a man was stoned to death by community members after he assaulted his wife with a panga in Mbooni East, Makueni County (Wote, Makueni). [size=no report]

On 13 June 2020, members of two rival matatu cooperatives fought over control of a bus terminal in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia), after one changed their office location. Police were on the scene to disperse the fighting. [size=no report]
On 14 June 2020, suspected al Shabaab members raided a village in Fino near Mandera (Mandera East, Mandera) and sexually assaulted two young girls.

column16: Capital FM; The Star (Kenya); Daily Nation (Kenya)
column17: On 14 June 2020, clashes between Borana and Gabra communities left four boys dead at a watering point in Saku subcounty (Saku, Marsabit).

On 14 June 2020, National Police Reservists repulsed an Al-Shabaab attack on a telecommunications mast at Warankara in Lafey (Lafey, Mandera). One police officer and one militant were killed. Several injuries reported. Conflicting reports suggest that three policemen were killed.

On 14 June 2020, residents in Nakuru (Nakuru Town East, Nakuru) demonstrated at the police station after a man who was arrested, committed suicide. The demonstrators accused police of murdering the man. [size=no report]
On 15 June 2020, residents marched in Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi) against police brutality during the national coronavirus curfew. [size=no report]

Around 15 June 2020 (as reported), community members demonstrated along the Marsabit-Isiolo highway near Marsabit (Saku, Marsabit) after four people from the Rendilles group were killed in a suspected tribal attack. [size=no report]

column16: Citizen (Kenya); People Daily; Media Max Network
column17: On 15 June 2020, matatu operators blocked the highway in Rironi (Limuru, Kiambu) with more than 300 vehicles. The demonstration was against the mounting of a roadblock which they say has interrupted their business. [size=at least 300]
On 15 June 2020, two police officers severely assaulted and injured a man in Litein (Buret, Kericho) during the national coronavirus curfew.
Around 21 June 2020 (as reported), a man was severely assaulted and injured by police in Mpeketoni (Lamu West, Lamu) during the enforcement of the national coronavirus lockdown.
On 24 June 2020, hundreds of boda boda drivers demonstrated against the poor state of the Kitale-Endebess road in Endebess sub county (Endebess, Trans Nzoia). [size=hundreds]
On 24 June 2020, suspected al-Shabaab members looted shops and set them alight in Ijara (Garissa). No fatalities reported.

column16: Kenya Standard; Citizen (Kenya); The Star (Kenya); Daily Nation (Kenya)
column17: On 25 June 2020, a police officer fatally shot a man who intervened when a police officer demanded a bribe from a boda boda driver in Lessos near Nandi Hills (Nandi Hills, Nandi) for not wearing a face mask during the national coronavirus curfew.

column16: Kenya Standard; Citizen (Kenya); Daily Nation (Kenya); The Star (Kenya); Al Jazeera
column17: On 25 June 2020, dozens of demonstrators, including boda boda drivers, stormed Lessos Police Station in Lessos near Nandi Hills (Nandi Hills, Nandi) after a police officer fatally shot a man who intervened when the officer demanded a bribe from a boda boda driver for not wearing a face mask during the national coronavirus curfew. The house of the police commander was set alight. Police used teargas and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. Two fatalities reported in some reports and three in others. [size=dozens]
On 26 June 2020, residents demonstrated in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) over a power outage which has lasted for one and a half months. [size=no report]
On 30 June 2020, a mob attacked a woman in Nambale town (Nambale, Busia) after a man was supposedly killed in her house. Police intervened. [size=no report]
On 4 July 2020, al-Shabaab members attacked a police station in Fafi village (Fafi, Garissa). No fatalities reported.
On 4 July 2020, Oloirien and Maasai community members clashed over land in in the Mikululo area (Kajiado Central, Kajiado). One person was killed and four injured.
On 4 July 2020, community members killed a man suspected of killing his brother in Kodera Forest near Homa Bay (Homa Bay). [size=no report]

On 5 July 2020, community members set alight the Rioma Police Station near Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) after police fatally shot a man who sold hand sanitizer during the coronavirus curfew (coded separately). [size=no report]
Around 5 July 2020, police fatally shot a man selling hand sanitizers during the national coronavirus curfew in Rioma near Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii).
On 5 July 2020, two Pokot herders were injured after Turkana raiders attacked Atirir village near Salawa (Tiaty, Baringo).
On 6 July 2020, community members killed four suspected livestock thieves in Mithuthini village near Wanguru (Mwea, Kirinyaga). [size=no report]

Around 7 July 2020 (as reported), a group of elderly women demonstrated in Mundoro village near Gatundu (Gatundu South, Kiambu) after their tenants defaulted on rent, demanding the tenants to leave their property. [size=no report]

column16: Kenya Standard; Capital FM; AFP; VOA; Daily Nation (Kenya); Citizen (Kenya); The Star (Kenya)
column17: On 7 July 2020, hundreds of activists staged the annual Saba Saba march in several areas in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi), including Kayole, Dandora, Mathare, and Kiamaiko, demanding an end to police brutality during the enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds and arrested 56. [size=hundreds]

On 7 July 2020, suspected Al Shabaab members hijacked and kidnapped 8 people in the Dabacity area near Wajir (Wajir East, Wajir). Police recovered the vehicle. No casualties and/or fatalities reported.

On 8 July 2020, mourners set a house, vehicle and crops alight in Kalyet near Londiani (Kipkelion East, Kericho) after a funeral was stopped by a court order over defamation claims. The property belonged to a woman who filed the claim after she was accused of bewitching the deceased woman. [size=no report]
On 8 July 2020, community members killed a man accused of rape in Matondoni village near Lamu (Lamu West, Lamu). [size=no report]

Around 9 July 2020 (as reported), the bodies of two teenagers who went missing after herding livestock were found dead with arrows in the corpses in the Maasai Mau forest near Olposimoru (Narok South, Narok).

On 9 July 2020, over 20 suspected Al Shabaab militants clashed with police forces during an attack on a communications mast in Korakora County near Garissa (Dujis, Garissa). Police repulsed the attackers. No fatalities and/or casualties reported.

On 10 July 2020, armed cattle raiders attacked and injured a cattle herder in Nassoukro, near Kabarnet (Baringo Central, Baringo), and made off with over 100 head of cattle. The herder later died from his injuries.

On 13 July 2020, more than 200 youth barricaded roads with rocks and lit bonfires near Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi), accusing the government of excluding them from a government empowerment project. Police intervened and the youth threw canisters used to disperse them back at police. [size=more than 200]

On 13 July 2020, community members attacked a miraa driver accused of killing a boda boda driver in Nyangati village near Wanguru (Mwea, Kirinyaga). The mob attacked and seriously injured two police officers who intervened. [size=no report]

On 13 July 2020, a man, suspected to be a member of the Al Shabaab, was killed by a bomb he was planting on the roadside in Geneva near Mandera (Mandera East, Mandera). It is believed the bomb targeted security agents who frequently use the route.
Around 13 July 2020 (as reported), residents demonstrated in Laikipia (Laikipia East, Laikipia) against insecurity in the area following the killing of a teacher by armed men. [size=no report]

On 14 July 2020, residents of Kaswanga village demonstrated at the Tom Mboya Level IV Hospital in Rusinga Island near Homa Bay (Homa Bay, Homa Bay) against the change of the hospital to a coronavirus isolation center. [size=no report]

On 18 July 2020, women's rights activists demonstrated in Sirende Location near Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia), demanded police action after a man battered his wife several times before leaving her for his partner. [size=no report]

column7: FORD-Kenya: Forum for the Restoration of Democracy-Kenya
column17: Around 18 July 2020 (as reported), youth supporters of a FORD-K MP clashed with police after police intervened in a meeting taking place at the local MP's house near Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) during coronavirus related policing. Three journalists were injured. [size=no report]
Around 19 July 2020 (as reported), an armed group of another community attacked and killed a young herder boy in Marti (Samburu North, Samburu) and stole a hundred goats and seventy cattle.

On 21 July 2020, hundreds of demonstrators marched to the Kibos Sugar Factory in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) after three people were killed in an accident allegedly caused by a worker of the factory. Police dispersed the crowd. [size=hundreds]
On 22 July 2020, suspected Al Shabaab members burned settlements in the area surrounding Yumbis (Dadaab, Garissa) following an earlier armed clash with police in Yumbis.

column16: Citizen (Kenya); East African Standard; The Star (Kenya)
column17: On 22 July 2020, about 20 suspected Al Shabaab members used explosions at the Yumbis Rural Border Patrol Unit police camp (Dadaab, Garissa). The explosions were preceded by heavy gunfire between police and the suspected Al Shabaab members. One police officer succumbed from his injuries and three fatalities reported.

On 23 July 2020, members of Losesia Group Ranch removed a land beacon during a demonstration against land encroachments near Archers Post (Samburu East, Samburu). It is alleged that the beacon was erected by land grabbers. [size=no report]

Around 24 July 2020 (as reported), residents demonstrated on the Eldoret - Kisumu road near Eldoret (Ainabkoi, Uasin Gishu), demanding the arrest of a man accused of assaulting women and children in the area. The accused was in custody but officers on duty allowed the suspect to go for a short call. He did not return. [size=no report]

On 25 July 2020, locals demonstrated in Garissa (Dujis, Garissa), demanding the release a murder suspect by police. 2 people were fatally shot by police repsonding to the demonstration. [size=no report]

On 25 July 2020, hundreds of boda boda riders engaged with police in what was reported as running battles in Eldoret (Ainabkoi, Uasin Gishu) after the murder of their chairperson. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=hundreds]
On 27 July 2020, suspected cattle raiders shot and injured a teenager from another ethnic group herding livestock in the Olmariko area near Olpusimoru in Narok North subcounty.

On 27 July 2020, youth militias clashed across two days of inter-ethnic in Olposimoru (Narok North, Narok) in response to the injury of teenager herding livestock in the Olmariko area near Olpusimoru by suspected cattle raiders. Three others injured with arrows. The ethnicies of the rival groups were not reported.

On 28 July 2020, tens of youth clashed in Olposimoru (Narok North, Narok) in response to the injury of teenager herding livestock in the Olmariko area near Olpusimoru by suspected cattle raiders. Two people were killed on the second day of fighting (reports differ on fatalities) and three others injured with arrows.

On 28 July 2020, the MCA for Mlango Kubwa was hospitalised after being assaulted by police officers in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi), after she and other MCAs attempted to serve the speaker an impeachment.

Around 29 July 2020 (between 29 - 30 July), violence erupted in five villages - Naisiida, Teegat, Olengape, Esoit and Kilapa near Olposimoru (Narok North, Narok) in response to the injury of teenager herding livestock in the Olmariko area near Olpusimoru by suspected cattle raiders. More than 30 houses were set alight, one person was killed and eight injured.

On 30 July 2020, two people, including a a Nyumba Kumi member, were injured with arrows when they were attacked by 10 youth in Ndoswa (Molo, Nakuru). The attack is suspected to be related to a land dispute and the recent evictions overseen by the Kenya Forest Service in Marioshoni area. One fatality reported.

On 31 July 2020, several houses were set alight and 107 cows impounded by police during a police raid in Doldol village in Samburu East (Kiamumbi, Samburu East, Samburu). More than 400 residents fled the village. According to some reports, some children are missing. No fatalities and/or casualties.

On 1 August 2020, a group of people, armed with crude weapons fatally assaulted a woman and seriously injured her husband over a land dispute in Kathuma village, Machakos county (Machakos Town, Machakos).

On 3 August 2020, a mob attacked the ODM offices in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu), in response to an earlier attack on County Public Service Board offices by youths affiliated with the ODM. [size=no report]

On 3 August 2020, youth armed with rungus, machetes, and hammers stormed the County Public Service Board offices in Milimani in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu), demanding employment. Five people were injured, including the chairman. The group was reportedly led by the vice-chairman of the ODM. [size=no report]
Around 3 August 2020 (as reported), Matatu operators demonstrated against the recent relocation of a terminus in Nakuru (Nakuru Town East, Nakuru). [size=no report]

Around 4 August 2020 (as reported), twelve people were arrested after two houses and a sugarcane plantation were set alight in renewed clashes in Transamara West (Trans Mara, Narok South, Narok) over cattle rustling. Police intervened before any casualties. Police officers seized three bows and 12 arrows from individuals who were engaged in a fight in the area.
On 4 August 2020, residents barricaded the Mirundi- Kevote road in Embu (Manyatta, Embu) to demonstrate against the slow construction of the road. [size=no report]
On 4 August 2020, patients in isolation due to the coronavirus demonstrated at the Kericho County Hospital (Ainamoi, Kericho) over a lack of food. [size=no report]

On 7 August 2020, members of the public attacked police officers and rescued a suspect of defilement who had been arrested in Murkan area within Transmara East, formerly known as Rift Valley near Kilgoris (Narok South, Narok). [size=no report]

On 8 August 2020, community members attacked police officers at the Madogo police station in Bura near Hola (Galole, Tana River). The police officers attempted to arrest two suspects accused of rape when the community attacked them. A police officer was injured after being attacked with a rungu. [size=no report]

column16: Media Max Network; East African Standard; Daily Nation (Kenya)
column17: On 8 August 2020, street traders pelted the motorcade of the health minister with stones in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) during a demonstration after their business stalls were demolished. The traders blocked the main entrance, demanding to be addressed by the governor, accusing the county government of not providing them with any masks and sanitisers at the markets during the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]
Around 8 August 2020 (as reported), residents demonstrated in Narok (Narok North, Narok) over the poor state of the roads connecting Olposimoru and Olkurto trading centres. [size=no report]

Police officers accused of detaining and raping two women
An unidentified armed group (Lesotho) shot opposition MP Molobeli Soulo in the leg.
Protesters (Lesotho) gathered outside parliament chant praise as PM Mosisili topples the government, forming a new Democratic Congress (DC) government.
Students riot in Mafeteng over inflated tuition and book fees. Destroy school property.
Litjobo, a Democratic Congress (DC) candidate, was attacked as he walked out of Good Times Cafe by an unidentified armed group (Lesotho).
Former labour minister & ABC party MP Sello Clement Machakela was shot dead at his home Monday night.
Protesters (Lesotho) from a textile factory gathered spontaneously at a DC rally, heckling the PM.
3 men were shot dead on Friday night by soldiers from Ha-Motanyane Military Barracks in Mafeteng under unclear circumstances.
Riots erupted in Thetsane industrial area as opposition supporters protested a DC rally led by Mosisili. 12 injured a police calmed riot.
Military forces of Lesotho (1996-) soldiers beat 6 men with guns before making them roll on the ground on at Sea Point. They have since been arrested for misconduct.
2 military forces of Lesotho (1996-) members attacked 2 police forces of Lesotho (1996-) members, accusing them of being drunk in uniform.
Military forces of Lesotho (1996-) member shot a civilian following an argument.
3 Lesotho Congress for Democracy (LCD) supporters were injured when they were attacked by a gang of youths near Peka on Sunday night.

The strike at the Metolong Dam project turned violent on Monday as workers pelted their boss with stones. Also injured in the violent confrontation was Hlalefang Seoaholimo, the national organiser of the Lesotho Workers Association (Lewa). Matters came to a head on Monday after Song allegedly reneged on an agreement to award a salary increment to the striking workers.
A vigilante mob torched the home of a man they believed to be a murder.
Two people are kill and six injured over a clash involving the control of land.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Lesotho (2012-2015)
column17: Coup/Military takeover: Army units returned to their barracks after surrounding and occupying government buildings as part of an alleged aborted coup against the government. Police stations remain mostly deserted and police are allegedly in hiding.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Lesotho (2012-2015)
column16: Al Jazeera; Deutsche Welle; Daily Dispatch (South Africa); Sowetan (South Africa); Times (South Africa)
column17: Gunshots were heard in Maseru and government/police buildings have been occupied by military units in what is believed to be a coup d'etat. The headquarters of the police was occupied, as well as other major police stations, and the premiers residence surrounded and attacked. Private radio stations have been taken off the air and phone lines cut. 1 police officer was killed and at least nine others seriously injured as the army disarmed police. Police officers have abandoned police stations allegedly for fear of being killed. It is believed a crime probe targetting the Deputy PM and influential army members motivated the attacks.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Lesotho (2012-2015)
column17: Non-violent activity: Suspected armed soldiers attacked the home of the newly appointed commander of the Lesotho Defence Force, Lt.-Gen. Mahao just after the previous commander Kamoli (allegedly behind the attack) was dismissed by the King on Friday. It was believed to be an assassination attempt but no casualties were reported. Mahaos whereabouts are now unknown.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Lesotho (2012-2015)
column17: Movement of forces: Former commander of the Lesotho armed forces Tladi Kamoli, who was fired by Lesothos PM, has ""emptied the countries arsenal and led troops into the mountains"" following an alleged coup attempt.

Security Measures: South African special forces escorted PM Thabane back to Maseru, and are staying to protect his residence and those of key officials. South African police units are also in the capital bolstering the Lesotho police force, which has returned to their HQ for the first time since the alleged coup began.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Lesotho (2012-2015)
column17: ""Police and military exchanged gunfire in Lesothos capital Maseru in the early hours of Friday."" It was not clear who fired first, but no injuries were reported.

Movement of forces: 39 police officers from Namibia were sent to Lesotho to act as observers to the ongoing political unrest. They were instructed to avoid political involvement and act purely as observers over the next three months, with a possible extension until the next elections.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Lesotho (2012-2015)
column17: Two policemen were wounded during a shootout between the force and the military outside the neighbouring houses of a senior government official and a military officer who is reportedly wanted in connection with the attempted coup.

column8: Mutiny of Military Forces of Lesotho (2012-2015)
column17: Agreement: South Africas deputy president has held secret talks with renegade Lesotho military commander Kamoli, who has been leading a small group of fighters since an attempted coup in August. This meeting may be a breakthrough in attempts to mediate between Kamoli and the Lesotho government.

column8: Mutiny of Military Forces of Lesotho (2012-2015)
column17: Agreement: Three top military and police commanders implicated in recent political turmoil agreed to step down as part of a deal brokered by South African mediator, Ramaphosa.
A local radio presenter was physically attacked by a chairperson of All Basotho Convention (ABC) Youth League at an ABC political party rally at Setsoto Stadium in Maseru.

Clash between Lesotho Defence Forces and two soldiers that were former bodyguards for Lesothos Prime Minister Tom Thabane. The former bodyguards refused to stop at a security checkpoint and started shooting at Lesotho Defence Force soldiers controlling access to the SADC offices near the presidential palace. LDF soldiers returned fire, the two soldiers/fomer bodyguards were wounded and one private security guard was shot and killed. The former bodyguards are thought to be responsible for tipping off Thabane of the failed coup in August 2014, which allowed Thabane to flee his residence before it was attacked by suspected army soldiers.

Protesters gathered in the street after a court postponed judgment in a case involving All Basotho Convention leader Thabane and the appointment of Kanalelo Mosito as president of the Court of Appeal.

Maaparankoe Mahao, former commander of the Defence Force Lesotho, was assassinated by soldiers at his home on the outskirts of Maseru, allegedly part of a military campaign to rid the country of those loyal to Prime Minister Thabane.
Arrests: Body of a solider found in a dam. He had been recently arrested for suspected coup plotting.
Vigilante militia kill the wife of a man on trial for murder and sexual assault.

National University of Lesotho Professor Mafa Sejanamane is attacked non-fatally in his house by unknown gunmen. The attack came a few days after the current coalition government activists complained on local and South African media that Prof. Sejanamane political analysis supports the main opposition All Basotho Convention.
A Zimbabwean newspaper editor who published a column satirising a Lesotho military commander was shot by unidentified gunmen in Maseru.
09 July. A human rights defender was shot four times outside his home in Ha Thamae, Maseru, Lesotho by an unknown group.

A Lesotho soldier is missing and another four of the countries nationals have been killed after they were allegedly ambushed by South African cattle raiders in separate attacks in the Maluti Mountains.
Movement of forces: A 258-strong regional force was deployed to Lesotho to ease security concerns in the landlocked kingdom after the killing of the country's top army commander in September.
The wife of the incoming prime minister was shot dead in Ha Masana village within the Mazenod community area.
The Lesotho Defence Force (LDF) commander was shot dead during a gun battle with other members of the Lesotho Defense Force at Ratjomose barracks (Outside Maseru). In total, three people were killed.

Movement of forces: The Southern African Development Community (SADC) has deployed a standby force from South Africa, Angola and Mozambique into Lesotho, as the regional bloc moves to avert another bout of instability prompted by this week's assassination of Lesotho Defence Force (LDF) commander.

On 15 August, police fired rubber bullets at protesting textile factory workers in Maseru, Lesotho. The protesters in Maseru are calling for a $150-a-month entry-level wage at the mostly Chinese-owned factories where they work.

column7: LTTU: Lesotho Teachers Trade Union; LAT: Lesotho Association of Teachers; LeSPA: Lesotho School Principals Association
column17: November, exact date not known. Members of three unions went on strike to press the government to grant them salary increments and review their working conditions.
On 28 November, some 200 SADC soldiers deployed a year ago to bolster security in Lesotho after the killing of the country's top army commander have left the landlocked kingdom.

14 February. Villagers from Ha-Thuntsane, Maseru, have burned two men suspected of cattle rustling. The mob beat the men with wooden sticks, followed by hanging burning tyres around their necks. [size=no report].

column7: Labour Group (Lesotho); LAT: Lesotho Association of Teachers
column17: 25 February. Teachers, represented by the Lesotho Association of Teachers (LAT), embarked on a strike, demanding better working conditions. [size=no report].

column7: Labour Group (Lesotho); NACTWU: National Clothing Textile and Allied Workers Union
column17: 08 April. Johnson workers, along with the National Clothing Textile and Allied Workers Union (NACTWU), staged a demonstration in Ha Maqele, Maputsoe. The demonstration was in response to increased working hours and wage payments. [size=no report].
1 June. Three armed men tried to kidnap the bodyguard of the All Basotho Convention (ABC) leader Nqosa Mahao over the weekend in Maseru. The bodyguard shot and killed two of the men. [size=3].

17 June. Rival factions of the All Basotho Convention (ABC), ABC-Thabane Faction and ABC-Mahao faction, almost clashed inside the All Basotho Convention (ABC) offices in Maseru after the Prime Minister, Thomas Thabane, expelled four committee members. A man believed to be from the pro-Thabane tried to open a door, a group of people believed to be pro-Mahao supporters then hit and kicked him. The man then ran to pro-Thabane supporters, where a woman pulled out a gun.

26 June. The youth from Maseru marched to Sefikeng sa Moshoeshoe to hand over a petition to Prime Minister Thomas Thabane, demanding more job opportunities. The petition also called for legislation to protect the LGBT community. The petition also called for clarification on funding for students. [size=300].

On or around 21 January 2020, Makhoakhoeng in Maseru, accused the South African National Defence Force (SANDF) of cattle rustling and harassing residents in the area.

On 5 February 2020, supporters of the first lady of Lesotho gathered outside the Maseru Magistrates' Court (Maseru) to show support during her court hearing on the suspected killing of the wife of the prime minister in 2017. [size=no report]

On 25 February 2020, ABC supporters demonstrated in Maseru (Maseru), demanding that the prime minster step down, due to him being questioned for the murder of his wife in 2017. [size=no report]

column17: On 10 March 2020, trade unions, including NACTWU, UNITE, IDUL, LESWU and LEWA, marched in Maseru (Maseru), demanding a 20 percent increase for textile workers and 17 percent for other sectors across the board. [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (Lesotho); NACTWU: National Clothing Textile and Allied Workers Union; UNITE: United Textile Employees; IDUL: Independent Democratic Union of Lesotho; LESWU: Lentsoe la Sechaba Workers Union; LEWA: Lesotho Workers Association
column17: On 17 March 2020, trade unions, including NACTWU, UNITE, IDUL, LESWU and LEWA, marched in Maseru (Maseru), demanding a 20 percent increase for textile workers and 17 percent for other sectors across the board. [size=no report]
On 30 March 2020, police and soldiers beat people who did not heed to the 21 day coronavirus lockdown, and forced them to roll on the ground in Maseru (Maseru). No fatalities were reported.

On 18 April 2020, the Prime Minister of Lesotho deployed the army on the streets of Maseru (Maseru, Lesotho) to ""restore law and order"", a day after the constitutional court ruled that his decision to suspend Parliament was ""irrational"". The PM is under pressure to step down after police said they suspected him of a hand in the murder of his estranged wife in 2017.
Around 15 July 2020 (month of), a man was beaten and ordered to eat his own feces by the police in Maseru (Maseru). The extent of the man's injuries were not reported.

On 19 August 2020, street vendors set garbage and tires on fire, and threw stones at shops in the Maseru Central Business District, Maseru (Maseru) after the government failed to deliver a promised coronavirus relief fund to them. The police were called to disperse the group and arrested a number of vendors. [size=no report]

On 25 August 2020, hundreds of vendors took to the streets in Maseru (Maseru) in a demonstration against the delay in releasing promised coronavirus grants from the government. The police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the group, who did not have permission to stage the demonstration, which led to several episodes of tires being burnt, and street blockages with boulders during the day. Several people were arrested. [size=hundreds]
Around 26 August 2020 (week of), two men were beaten and injured by police officers in Quthing (Quthing). The two were summoned by the police, threatened and beaten to confess to a robbery.
Around 29 August 2020 (weekend of), a man was fatally assaulted by the police in Mafeteng (Mafeteng).
Around 29 August 2020 (weekend of), a man was beaten by the police in Butha-Buthe (Butha-Buthe) for violating traffic regulations. The extent of the man's injuries were not reported.
Around 1 September 2020 (as reported), a man was beaten and injured by police officers in Semonkong (Maseru), after he had gone to file a report that he had been assaulted by a fellow villager.
Around 2 September 2020 (as reported), a person was tortured to death by the police in Mafeteng (Mafetenge).
Teachers and students gather to protest for higher teacher pay.
Police forces violently evict protesting students and teachers. The Liberty party describes the eviction as ""police brutality."" A number of rapes were reported.
Supporters of a Montserro County political aspirant attack a journalist. 6

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: A militia group loyal to the former Cote dIvoire administration crosses into Liberia and kills two farmers.

At a mass rally held in Kwedin, the citizens said their plan to institute a ""protest vote"" against President Sirleaf is based on her failure to implement any of her campaign promises made to them during the 2005 elections.
Lenn Eugene Nagbe, the Deputy Campaign Manager of the ruling Unity Party (UP), was attacked by arsonists on his home. Though the attack was around 2am he was able to escaped unharmed.
Chairman of the opposition Congress for Democratic Change, was attacked after disputing an election primary.
Members of the opposition Liberty Party assault four journalists who were trying to cover a story involving their leader being released from prison.
Eleven students and supporters of the Transformation Party presidential candidate Kennedy Sandy were intentionally mowed down by an automobile when a group assembled to welcome their candidate.
Prior to the general election of October 11, two cars holding Unity Party officials became victims of an arson attack.

Presidential candidates from the Unity and INPFL parties protest their placement on a ballot. The two candidates were listed as numbers 7 and 8 and both have the surname ""Johnson"". The groups thought this would be confusing to voters.

The local headquarter of the ruling Unity Party in Paynesville, outside Monrovia, was set ablaze early Saturday morning at about 1 AM. It is has not yet been established who did the act, however, Unity Party is assuming that the arson attack on the local headquarter was instigated by some opposition members who are losing the just ended October 11 election.
At around 3 a.m. on Monday, unidentified assailants in a red pickup threw a Molotov cocktail at Love FM, a station favorable to main opposition party Congress for Democratic Change, Jallah Griefield.

Insecurity continues in Liberia ahead of the presidential runoff election November 8 with two petrol bomb attacks on the homes of supporters of the ruling Unity Party in the western Monrovia suburb of Barnersville Estate.
A small crowd gathered at the Congress for Democratic Change (CDC) for a ""peace vigil"" in support of Tubman, a candidate in the runoff elections.
A Unity Party helicopter dropped thousands of election pamphlets across the city urging supporters to boycott runoff elections.
Supporters of the CDC Party and the Unity Party clash before a runoff election, one dead.

Thousands of boisterous supporters of his Congress for Democratic Change gathered outside party headquarters, where the atmosphere was tense as riot police blocked the road after protestors attempted to block advancing United Nations water cannon. The protestors, who chanted slogans such as ""we want justice, we want freedom."" Later in the day CDC supporters exchanges gunfire with police forces. Four dead, plus injuries, 54 arrested. A candidate, Winston Tubman, accused the police of trying to assassinate him.

Peacekeepers remained outside the headquarters of the opposition Congress for Democratic Change overnight, following Mondays deadly violence between protesters and riot police. When a police van arrived at opposition headquarters Tuesday, it was met by an angry crowd shouting ""No Police."" Nigerian peacekeepers asked the police to leave, and they did.
Senator Gloria Musu Scott of the Unity Party claimed that her vehicle convoy had been attacked while on its way to Monrovia.
Angry protestors attacked CDC candidate George Weah at his home, though he was unharmed.
A group attacked National Chairman of the CDC, and other party officials at the CDC headquarters.

Assistant Information Minister for Culture Jacqueline Capehart was attacked while giving a speech. During the speech several youths began throwing stones at her before the group was arrested by police.

Assistant Information Minister for Culture Jacqueline Capehart was attacked while giving a speech. During the speech several youths began throwing stones at her before the group was arrested by police.
Two men destroyed the car of UP party official Eugene Nagbe with a petrol bomb in the yard of his home in Margibi County
Hundreds of Liberian opposition supporters gathered in Monrovia Monday for a funeral march to honor the victims of a police shooting that marred disputed elections earlier this month.

Police authorities in Monrovia say they have arrested at least three persons for allegedly desecrating or burning the flag of the Republic of Norway, and storming the European Union Headquarters in an unauthorized demonstration. ""[This] symbolizes our displeasure of the award given to one of the recipients, Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, who admitted to contributing US$10,000.00 to NPFLs action which killed 300,000 Liberians."" The protesting group also handed out anti-police flyers.

Liberia imposed a dusk-to-dawn curfew in the capital Monrovia on Friday and security forces fired teargas to disperse thousands of youths rampaging through the city, smashing car windows and burned tires in protest over late payment by the government for part-time jobs. Protesting/rioting lasted over two days.

Liberia imposed a dusk-to-dawn curfew in the capital Monrovia on Friday and security forces fired teargas to disperse thousands of youths rampaging through the city, smashing car windows and burned tires in protest over late payment by the government for part-time jobs. Protesting/rioting lasted over two days.
A large group of teachers gather to protest the non-payment by the government of back salaries.
No death has been reported, but properties were said to have been looted in Bilibokree, Juarzon Statutory District after two rival political parties clash after an argument of alleged electioneering.

Community college students ""rampage"", disrupting the induction of Superintendent Christiana Dagadu in Sanniqueilie. Although there has been no report of any injury and destruction of properties yet, but the situation is said to have lasted for almost two hours.
Finance Minister Amara Konneh escaped a petrol bomb attack on his residence unharmed. Perpetrators unknown.
Security Measures: Liberia on Saturday closed its border with Cote dIvoire, a day after seven UN peacekeepers and eight civilians were killed during raids in Ivorian villages near the frontier.

Two students are wounded during a riot at the University of Liberia. It is believed to have been started in reaction to a merger of two political parties. The Student Unification Party was also believed to have been involved.
Arrests: Liberian forces arrested four members of the Laurent Gbago militia who are believed to be responsible for a recent attack on UN Peacekeepers in the Cote dIvoire.

Ghana-based former members of the Gbagbo regime had created a ""military structure,"" hired mercenaries and established several training camps in eastern Liberia. The investigators said the aim was to topple Ouattaras government.
Students of the Tubman National Institute of Medical Arts convene outside the national capital building to demand $3,500 from the government owed to them under contract.
Teachers boycott classes over ""several weeks"", gathering outside the Education Ministry building, demanding salary increases
Arrests: Liberian police forces arrest a high profile member of the Laurent Gbagbo militia. The man, Bobby Shappy Julu, is considered ""the principal brain"" of the group.

Students of the Monrovia Consolidated School System (MCSS) demonstrated near the Ministry of Foreign Affairs insisting that striking teachers demands for salary increment be met. Many of the protesters set up road blocks.
The congregation of a church gathers to protest the closure of a Catholic radio station.
A large group gathers of protest the possibility of gay marriage recognized by law in Liberia.

Two groups of youths, both anti and pro-Robert Kilby, a government auditor, gathered at the office of the General Auditing Commission building. The groups want either resignation or reinstatement of the office holder.
A pro and anti Kilby protest continues for a second non-consecutive day outside the office of the GAC.
Medical students protest County Health Officer, Dr. Aaron Kollies refusal to allow them to intern at a hospital.

Movement of forces: Liberian forces stationed along the border with the Ivory Coast have begun pulling out of the area. The soldiers were deployed along the borderlines including the Beyea border in Toe Town, Grand Gedeh County following heavy fighting between the Ivorian Government and rebels at the Perkin Military Barracks close to the Liberian side.
Residents gather to protest the Ministry of Public Works for its recent demolition of housing structures. The government plans a large road in the affected area.

Anti-United Nations Mission in Liberia protesters gathered outside the Ministry of Justice building in Monrovia to protest against alleged corruption by head officials. A journalist is arrested by police during the event.

Approximately 700 students of the University of Liberia protested an increased student fee outside the capital building during President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf's annual massage to the Legislature. The student leader of the event was arrested.

Police forces arrested several young people who were protesting against the employment of foreigners by the management of an oil company. Some accused the police of ""flogging"" the protesters, however the police deny this.
Employees of a Chinese Company riot after a co-worker is allegedly killed. At least one company official was held hostage by the mob.

Residents of District #8 in Montserrado County besieged the residence of Representative Acarus Gray on Capitol Bye-Pass in Monrovia. The group accused Gray of a failure to meet campaign promises made in 2011.

The Suspended Acting Monrovia City Mayor Mary Broh narrowly escaped death and arrest from hundred of Liberia youths at the Temper of Justice in Monrovia as they protested controversial legislation. Reports indicate the group physically assaulted the mayor.

A group of Monrovia residents under the banner 'Sad Citizens' stormed the residence of President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, opposing the resignation of Acting City Mayor Mary Broh. The mayor had recently resigned, succumbing to political pressure.

A Christian group gathered outside the capital building in Monrovia to demand the legislature return Liberia to an officially Christian nation, as it was before the adoption of the 1986 constitution. The number of those gathered was not estimated.

On 29 April 2013, police clashed with a local armed militia as they attempted to kill a suspected murderer in Zia Town (Konobo, Grand Cedeh). There were reports of gunfire and injuries, though the police deny this claim.

A youth group in Zorzor District, Lofa County under the banner of ""Lofa Youth for Peace and Good Governance"" stage a protest against the reconciliatory conference organized by two senior officials of the county.
