The group believes one of the officials has undisclosed knowledge of suspicious death in the area.
A group youths who formed a vigilante squad physically assault four people you suspect to be criminals over the course of two days.
A group youths who formed a vigilante squad physically assault four people you suspect to be criminals over the course of two days.
A group of students gather to protest the recent abduction of one of their teachers.
Riot outside entertainment center ends when police intervene and make arrests
Residents of Small Town Community clash with members of CDC
Residents riot to protest police actions; police open fire on rioters when the mob attacked a police post
Protest outside health clinic over death of local man
Private security at hospital attacks journalist who was reporting on conditions at the hospital
Students protest over state of the nation
Residents block roads to protest after their houses were demolished
Protest against China Mines for low salaries, poor working conditions
Protest against China Mines for low salaries, poor working conditions
Protest against China Mines for low salaries, poor working conditions
After a mental patient started cutting people, a mob broke out in response - wounding several people and killing one.
Former employees of Ministry of Finanace and Planning and Economic Affairs protested their jobs being made redundant.
Youth booed politicians for decision on Chinese mines
Student protest against arrears
Residents protested over a funeral home location. Police intervened.
Residents of Electoral District #4 marched to Buchanan to protest land being taken.
Residents of Electoral District #4 marched to Buchanan to protest land being taken.
Residents of District #4 resisted their land being surveyed by Equatorial Palm Oil company. Police intervened.
Police beat, arrested protesters. Civilians were injured to the point of hospitalisation.
Residents of District #4 resisted their land being surveyed by Equatorial Palm Oil company. Police intervened.
Motorcyclists stormed a police station to demand that a motorcycle theif be handed over.
Residents of Electoral District #4 marched to Buchanan to protest land being taken.
A man was beaten up by PYJ supporters who accused him of spying on them.
Protest against China Mines for low salaries, poor working conditions
Protest against China Mines for low salaries, poor working conditions
Protest against China Mines for low salaries, poor working conditions
After 4 days of protests against China mines, police shot rounds at protesters to disperse the crowd.
After a truck driver hit a motorcycle, a mob broke out and set the truck on fire. The police arrested 6 people connected with the truck burning.
Police and Salala Rubber Corporation Security Guards looted, beat, and tortured residents in Doekai Town.
A man was killed over a land dispute between the towns of Kpowin and Sahnquoi
Rioters burned down a police station in Arthington due to a police investigation of a simple assault case.
Protesters of the Ellen Step Down Campaign protested President Sirleafs arrival in Liberia. Police intervened.
Students protested outside the Temple of Justice for 11 people arrested for sedition to be released.
UN Panel of expert report claimed that there was a pro-Gbagbo rebel base in Eastern Liberia where rebels are trained and recruited to destabilise Ivory Coast.
Teachers protested for benefits to be paid.
Motorcyclists rioted over the death of their colleague in a road accident. Rioters set a gas and bus station on fire. Police intervened and were injured.
Students protested registration closing early.
Students protested registration closing early. Students threw stones. Police intervened, firing teargas.
Youth protesters demonstrated at the administrative building to be included in the draft oil reform law.
Motorcyclists protested the announcement of a motorcycle ban. The ban was instituted after riots in late October.
Employees of the Sime Darby Plantations rioted for increased salaries. Ers threw stones. RThe Plantation is on the Grand Cape Mount-Bomi border. Riots lasted two days.
Employees of the Sime Darby Plantations rioted for increased salaries. Ers threw stones. RThe Plantation is on the Grand Cape Mount-Bomi border. Riots lasted two days.
Protesters of Central Virginia Community and River Side Community blocked trucks from the River Sanding Mining Company.
A civil society group protested for the Monrovia Consolidated School System to improve school capacity.
An unidentified armed group robbed a store in Doe Community and left three people injured.
After police and youth bumped into each other in Sanniquellie, the youths took the police officers gun and beat up the officers.
Students at University of Liberia called for the resignation of the Vice President of Academic Affairs. Police intervened

column6: Former MODEL: Movement for Democracy in Liberia
column17: Recruitment: UN panel of experts reported that former MODEL rebels were recruiting Liberian mercenaries in Foya and Cape Mountfor for the conflict in Mali.
Teachers went to the Misitry of Education to demand salary arrears.
Anti-rape protest in Monrovia. President Johnson participated.

column8: UNMIL: United Nations Mission in Liberia (2003-)
column17: National UNMIL staff protested over poor working conditions. According to the New Zealand Herald, UNMIL peacekeepers manhandled protesters.
NPP broke out in a riot during a meeting. NPP members fought over whether a member violated a clause in the party constitution. Police intervened.

""A group of young men believed to be students of the state run University of Liberia or UL setup road blocks early Monday morning with burning tires before the entrance of the university campus and the Capitol Building housing members of the Legislature"". Rioters left before the police arrived.
A child was reported missing in Fish Town, reportedly abducted for 'Gboyo' ritualistic practices carried out by individuals aspiring for political power
In DioWappi in Jloh Statutory District, Grand kru County, rioters tried to prevent miners from entering the forest byt throwing stones. Police intervened.
Students protested at the capital ahead of Sirleafs speech meant to be given on the 27 Jan
Students set up barricades and destroyed the Vice Presidents car. Police arrested 10 students.
Members of the Liberian workforce protested at the Capital for the passage of a bill which would increase minimum wage.

Residents of Gbapa & surrounding towns in Northern Nimba county blocked the Arcelor Mittal steel company's operations, protesting the company's failure to pay compensation for farmland & crops destroyed during operations
Teachers protested over unpaid salaries at the Ministry of Education in Sinkor
A Police Support Unit officer flogged a journalist from the Liberia Women Democracy Radio in Kebbah community in Barnesville township
Students of Kakata Rural Teachers Training Institute (KRTTI) protested at the county education office in Margibi, calling for the removal of the KRTTI director
A child was reported missing in Bulah Town, reportedly abducted for 'Gboyo' ritualistic practices carried out by individuals aspiring for political power
Students & others protested at Gbarnga administration building, over delays in construction of the Bong Technical College
Employees of Kakata Rural Teachers Training Institute (KRTTI) protested over the reinstatement of the Institute director
Rubber plantations belonging to Salala Rubber Plantation Company in Margibi County, were set on fire, linked to residents water contamination concerns
Salala citizens seized Salala Rubber Corporation's nursery & stopped work for 2 days demanding that water contamination concerns be addressed
Palm plantations belonging to Equatorial Palm Oil company in District #4, Grand Bassa County, were set on fire, linked to land disputes with residents

79 civil society groups under the Liberian Business Association (LIBA) staged a mass demonstration in protest over the passage of a bill seeking to amend the 1999 Act establishing the Central Bank of Liberia
Students and faculty members of the Kakata Rural Teacher Training Institute demonstrated to demand the removal of Director Precious Brownell-Dennis
Motorcyclists attacked the vehicle of the Deputy Police Director in Monrovia after the car hit a moto driver. 3 officers were wounded & 40 residents arrested.
A suspected criminal was mobbed to death by unknown persons in Duala
Residents disrupted the groundbreaking ceremony for a latrine facility, protesting the location of the project.
Family members of the 40+ residents arrested for damaging the vehicle of the Deputy Police Director stormed the national police headquarters
Over 100 widows stormed a government building to demand their husbands payments
Protest over Ebola center in Kru Town

column7: NCDUL: Nigerian Community and Descendent Union in Liberia
column17: Allegedly naturalized Liberians of Nigerian descent protested in front of the Nigerian embassy against the Nigerian ambassador who they criticized for allegedly referring to them as ""criminals, thieves, and Boko-Haram agents""
Nigerians and their descendants in Liberia stormed the Nigerian Embassy in protest, riot occurred
Health workers in Liberia are protesting their working conditions, e.g. Lack of protective gear, particularly in relation to the recent outbreak of Ebola
Hundreds of youths who work for the Liberia Youth Empowerment Program blocked the Ministry of Youth and Sports demanding pay arrears owned to them

Employees of the Liberia Water and Sewer Corporation left theirs offices in protest to demand a salary increase, as well as retroactive pay and benefits; the protest was brought under control by Liberia security officers but no violence was reported

A fight broke out in Vai Town market; Rep. Vamouyan Konneh is accused of instigating the violence to get back at the family of Jenekai Coleman; he was seen attempting to wound Mr. Coleman with a knife; men with sticks and other ""deadly weapons"" also barricaded the front of Universal Import and Export Inc. owned by Colemans parents
Over 200 pre-service teachers from the University of Liberia protested in front of the Foreign Ministry, seeking benefits denied to them;

Police officers took a generator from a shopkeeper who tried to oppose them but was then beaten; some of the onlookers tried to come to his aid but were unable to prevent the police from taking his generator
Liberian women demonstrated in front of the Nigerian embassy in Sinkor to protest against the kidnapping of girls in Nigeria by Boko Haram

Aggrieved marketers, mainly women, in the Kakata general market attacked the offices of the Margibi County Superintendent with stones and other objects after accusing him of administrative malpractice and corruption; they then barricaded themselves within the offices, until police arrived and calmed the situation

Scores of widows of Armed Forces of Liberia soldiers protested in front of the National Legislature by taking off their clothes, demanding the benefits they say they are owed for the deaths of their former husbands; they were peacefully dispersed by the police
Widows of LPA soldiers protested again in front of the National Legislature to demand benefits for the deaths of their former husbands
A journalist at Radio Gompa in Nimba County was taken off air during his broadcast, mandhandled and flogged by men believed to be staffers at the Office of Nimba County Senator
A number of workers have observed work stoppages to protest ""the suspension of the workers union head"" since it occurred on May 26

column6: UNMIL: United Nations Mission in Liberia (2003-)
column17: Movement of forces: UNMIL has announced that has begun withdrawing peacekeeping troops from Butuo, the starting place of the Liberian civil war in December 1989
Youth under the banner of Youth for Progressive Action, gathered in front of the Ministry of Public Works, calling for the resignation of the Public Works Minister
Students under the banner ""Concerned Margibi University Students"" or MARUSA stormed the Capitol Building, accusing officials of mismanaging funds budgeted for development in Margibi County

column7: Youth for Progressive Action; United Conscious Students Association
column17: Youth under the banner of Youth for Progressive Action and United Conscious Students Association gathered in front of the Ministry of Public Works, calling for the resignation of the Public Works Minister. Police intervened to remove protesters by the entrance of the Ministry.

column8: Military Forces of Liberia (2006-2018) Presidential Guard
column9: UNMIL: United Nations Mission in Liberia (2003-)
column17: An angry mob armed with sticks and other deadly instruments went to the Executive Mansion, residence of the president of Liberia, to break down a fence which they said was disrupting water flow; they surprised and overpowered the EPS: Executive Protective Service and UNMIL officers on duty

Residents gathered at the Equatorial Palm Oil Company HQ in Buchanan to deliver a petition with over 90,000 signatures; only one of their members was allowed in, with traditional elders being forced to wait outside

Employees of the Ministry of Finance engaged in a go-slow action to protest against the plans of making some employees redundant as they merge with the Ministry of Planning and Economic Affairs; the employees got restless and started chanting anti-Finance Minister slogans, and were later asked to leave the premises by the police
Supporters of two canidates running for the Unity Party clashed in Bong in the run-up to the announcement of candidates for the county; another fight happened just before the results were called
Marketers, mostly women, set up road blocks to draw attention to their demands for justice in the murder of a security guard protecting the market they work at
The chairman of Abloteh was attacked by an ""agitator"" while he was en-route to a meeting; he was injured and was taken to a hospital in Greenville

A protest in Zolowee against the steel-producing giant Arcelor Mittal involving the setting up of roadblocks turned violent after police fired tear gas and shot into the air; rioters then fired on police with single-barrel hunting rifles and ambushed a police jeep, burned a bridge linking Sanniquellie to Yekepa, and causing substantial damage to properties owned by Arcelor Mittal; employees of the company were also taken hostage

A representative in the Liberian legislature has alleged he was arrested and beaten by police as he attempted to help calm the violence during the Nimba riots; he was later released after the intervention of other lawmakers
Arrests: Police arrested 40 people suspected of being involved in the Arcelor Mittal violence
Residents of some villages in Lofa County have chased away doctors attempting to screen communities for ebola with knives and stones.
Gbarnga residents demonstrated at the site of a recent armed robbery that left a teenager dead
Employees of the Liberia Maritime Authority staged a peaceful protest in front of the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning in demand of their salaries.
A peaceful protest was staged in front of the National Legislature against the sale of additional oil blocks in the country
Protesters barricaded one of the main entrances of the ELWA hospital to protest against the establishment of an Ebola Center in the hospitals compound.
A man set the conference room of the Ministry of Health on fire in protest of the death of his younger brother, whom he claimed died from Ebola.

Residents of Popalahun community staged a roadblock and attacked Liberian health workers employed by Samaritans Purse. They smashed the windshield of the jeep they were traveling in, slashed the tires with machetes and beat one workers with a hammer before they escaped.
Security Measures: President Sirleaf has declared a state of national emergency due to the ongoing ebola outbreak.
Members of the Duport Road community chased away an ebola burial team.

Two factions of CDC members clashed in the party HQ after angry CDC members, mainly youths, chased Chariman Solo out of the building, believing he means to ""sell out"" the party. The youths also attempted to attack journalists but were prevented by other CDC members. Some were injured.

Hundreds of youths of the St.Pauls Bridge Community in Monrovia clashed with polie over the removal of dead bodies from the community, after they blocked a road to bring attention tot he issue. Police fired tear gas to disperse the protesters and arrested some, but they were later released.
Residents caught someone they believed was attempting to poison a well and proceeded to beat him, but he managed to escape.
Residents of the New Georgia area set up road blocks to demand the government investigate well-poisoning claims in the capital.

column16: Front Page Africa; New Republic Liberia
column17: A man believed to be poisoning a well was attacked by youths wile being transported by police to their station. They threw stones which wounded several people, and threatened the suspect and the police. The man tried to hide in a shop, which was damaged by the mob and whose owners were also hurt. Two people were arrested after police back-up arrived.

Two men suspected of being robbers were detained by a Community Watch Team. Following this a mob formed and attempted to stop the Community Watch Team from taking them to the authorities, but the police intervened and took the suspects into custody.
Rioters in blocked Liberias busiest highway to protest the governments delay in collecting bodies of ebola victims. Police dispersed the protesters.
Youths in Clara Town gathered to protest against the slow removal of bodies from their community. Police responded by handcuffing and beating some of the protesters.
People gathered in front of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to protest against the declaration of a state of emergency. Police dispersed the protest and arrests were made.
A FrontPageAfrica reporter was beaten by police and arrested while covering at protest at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Journalists and other people gathered in front of the offices of the Chronicle and marched away shouting anti-government slogans in support of the Liberian media after police closed down the newspaper.

column16: Inquirer (Liberia); Reporters Sans Frontieres; New Republic Liberia
column17: ""Police raided the National Chronicle, broke down its front door, released teargas inside, seized two computers and arrested news editor Emmanuel Mensah, computer technician Emmanuel Logan and copy editor Philibert S. Browne. Roughed up at the time of their arrest, the three journalists were later released.""

Unidentified young attackers armed with clubs and some guns attacked and looted an ebola isolation centre in West Point. During/after the attack between 17 and 20 patients left the centre or were taken away by family members. No injuries were reported.
Heavy rioting took place in the West Point neighbourhood between residents and police in response to the imposition of a curfew and quarantine.

Officials of the CDC were arrested and ""brutalized"" by police officers, leading to some injuries. It was not reported why they were arrested, although many other CDC officials are already reported to be in custody.

Rioting continued for a second day in the West Point neighbourhood following the imposition of a quarantine. The riot started after a local representative sent police to get her family out. Police protecting the car fired into the air as the crowd became violent. The crowds engaged in stone throwing and looting of food and other supplies was reported. 4 residents were injured in the clashes. Police shot 15-year old Shaki Kamara, who died the following day. 2 others were allegedly also shot.
Security forces fired live rounds and tear gas to disperse a stone throwing crowd trying to break the quarantine on their neighbourhood of est Point. At least 4 people were injured.
Hundreds of angry youth in Schieflin Town near Duport protested the perceived secret burial of Ebola victims in their area. They dug up the body to move out of the area.
Medical staff at JFK Monrovia protested to demand better wages, insurance, better protective gear, among other things. This followed a recent protest on Sept.2.

A notorious criminal was found dead in the main street with marks of flogging and torture. It is believed he was the victim of mob violence. Other suspicious deaths have been reported in the community.

A protest by CDC youth against the political leader of the CDC occurred outside the residence of Ambassador George Weah. The protesters then stormed his residence and attempted to prevent him from attending the launch of an Ebola task force.

Residents of Nimba County gathered outside the main entrance of the Capitol Building in groups comprising of those in favor and those against the plenarys decision to invite Superintendent Fong Zwagele for questioning while the other group called on the President to dismiss the County Superintendent of Nimba.

Civilians protested in the street with flyers and materials after a women was raped, murdered, and her body found outside of a night club on Wednesday September 24. Women and youth protested to have the body removed from the area. No exact date of protests is mentioned.

Liberian police accused of beating a man to death with sticks and guns for breaking 11pm curfew in ELWA Junction in Paynesville. Body of the man was found lying near security shift. Seven officers have been suspended pending an investigation by the Crimes Services Division.

Residents of Paynesville set up road blocks, damaged two police vehicles, wounded two officers, and vandalised a police depot. Riot was caused by the discovery of the body of an unidentified man believed to be beaten to death by police on night of Sept. 26 for breaking 11pm curfew.

column7: MOLAC: Movement Against Corruption in Liberia; CLACI: Concerned Liberians Against Corruption and Impunity
column17: Protests calling for the resignation of President Sirleaf for supposed failure to address issues of corruption. Specific date and location of protest unavailable.

Salala Rubber Cooperation tappers rioted at plantation in Margibi County, blocking vehicles and destroying company property. Rioters claimed maltreatment by company management. Police intervened to calm riots. Several workers reportedly arrested.

Rioters seized a vehicle of health workers traveling to Kanwekan (coordinates unavailable) near Grand Kru County. Rioters believe health workers to be more concerned with picking up dead bodies than treating the sick.

Aggrieved Bassa Citizens protested at the administrative buildings of Grand Bass County, demanding the resignation of Superintendent Madam Etweeda Cooper and deputy superintendent for development Adonis Greeves. Superintendents are accused of misusing Ebola funds; President Sirleaf is accused of making the appointments without prior consultation with the legislative caucus of the county. Protests occurred on Oct. 8, 9 and 10.
Health workers at The Island Clinic in Monrovia protest throughout the week, concerned with low wages and working conditions.

Aggrieved Bassa Citizens protested at the administrative buildings of Grand Bass County, demanding the resignation of Superintendent Madam Etweeda Cooper and deputy superintendent for development Adonis Greeves. Superintendents are accused of misusing Ebola funds; President Sirleaf is accused of making the appointments without prior consultation with the legislative caucus of the county. Protests occurred on Oct. 8, 9 and 10.

Aggrieved Bassa Citizens protested at the administrative buildings of Grand Bass County, demanding the resignation of Superintendent Madam Etweeda Cooper and deputy superintendent for development Adonis Greeves. Superintendents are accused of misusing Ebola funds; President Sirleaf is accused of making the appointments without prior consultation with the legislative caucus of the county. Protests occurred on Oct. 8, 9 and 10.

Over the weekend, Aggrieved Bassa Citizens presented a 10-point petition to the Grand Bassa County Legislative Caucus, outlinging demands for the resignation of Grand Bassa County Superintendent Madam Etweeda Cooper and deputy superintendent for development Adonis Greeves, including alleged misuse of Ebola funds. Deputy Speaker of the Liberian House of Representatives Hans Barchue said President Sirleaf did not consult the legislative caucus of the county before appointing the superintendents.

Over the weekend, nurses and doctors protested at Island Clinic Ebola Treatment Unit in Monrovia. Protests aimed at Ministry of Health and Social Welfare for failure to address the salary reduction of nurses and doctors when transferred from John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital to Island Clinic.

column8: Military Forces of Liberia (2006-2018) Presidential Guard
column17: Protesters gathered at the Presidential Palace in Voinjama to allege that the Liberia Cocoa Company illegally appropriated lands. Officers of the presidential guard discharged batons and light weapons to disperse the crowd after President Sirleafs comments of shut up - go home immediately met with anger from the crowd. No injuries reported.
Health workers gathered before the Capitol Building in Monrovia to protest against hospital administrators switching the workers payroll status to the Ministry of Healths payroll.

Residents of Old Road in Monrovia erected road blocks after hearing gun shots and seeing blood in the street of an unidentified man. Rioters believed Police Commissioner Nimely to have been involved in the shooting and demanded to know more information.

Children between the ages of 12 to 16 gathered before the Capitol Building, seat of the National Legislature on Oct. 23, seeking justice for Shaki Kamara, the teenager who died in a shootout in West Point in August. President Sirleaf had already ordered the Independent Human Rights Commission to carry out an investigation.
Protesters from the CDC: Congress 0f Democratic Change held a demonstration at the headquarters of the Liberian National Police to demand release of youth wing chair Jefferson Koijee.
Two men killed when a group of rioters went searching for an alleged robber in the Chicken Soup Factory Gulf community in Bassa Town, near Gardnersville.
Dozens of CDC protesters gathered near Monrovia Central Prison to greet Youth League Chairman Jeff Koijee after he was released on bail following 5 days of detention. One woman injured by police.

column16: Front Page Africa; Liberia News Agency; Heritage (Liberia)
column17: Residents of West Point rioted in Monrovia on Nov. 10, setting road block and demanding the resignation or reassignment of the Township Commissioner, Madam Miatta Haja Flowers. 6 arrested, including Leroy Ponpon.

column7: NTCL: National Traditional Council of Liberia; ABC: Aggrieved Bassa Citizens
column17: Traditional leaders, including National Traditional Council chairman John Taywayou, protested at the Buchanan Magisterial Court to withdraw a criminal case involving Grand Bassa financial officer Sylvester Taylor and Agrgrieved Bassa Citizens leader Du-Ben Cleon.
Riots in Monrovia between supporters of Montserrado County senatorial candidates Robert Sirleaf and George Weah left several wounded.

Supporters of Independent senatorial candidate Gabriel Buchanan Smith raided and vandalized Radio Gbehzohn after Smith was denied the purchase of airtime. The rioters destroyed transmitters, laptops and desktop computers. An arrest warrant was issued for Smith for allegedly instigating the riots.

Unidentified group used a petrol bomb to set fire to the home of senatorial candidate Robert Sirleafs campaign coordinator Flomo Yarsiah. Yarsiah and other members of the campaign were holding a meeting in the house at the time. No injuries reported.

Hundreds of widows of soldiers stormed the Capitol Building demanding benefits supposedly owed by the government. The women barricaded the main entrance to the building preventing traffic from entering.
CDC supporters threw stones at Robert Sirleafs campaign vehicle in PHP Blue Field area of Monrovia.
Supporters of Robert Sirleaf attacked CDC/Ambassador Weah supporters in Rally Town Market in Monrovia, using rocks and deadly weapons. Eight injured.
CDC supporters threw stones at Sirleafs convoy as it passed CDC Headquarters during Sirleafs campaign rally in Monrovia.

Several senators including Dan Morias (NPP) and Jewel Howard Taylor (NPP) marched at police headquarters in Monrovia to demand the release of Senator Lahai G. Lansanah and his wife, both arrested Wednesday (Dec. 24) in Tubmanburg following voters threats to set fire to the National Elections Commission Office.

Over the weekend of Dec. 27-28, hundreds of Muslim community members protested against the clearing of Zwedru Central Cemetary for new use as a burial site for Ebola victims. County authorities immediately ordered the relocation of the site to nearer the Ebola Treatment Center.

Towards the end of December 2014, rioters attacked and looted the homes of managers of the No Way Camp, Marloi Township, in Grand Bassa County, after paying to obtain jobs at the gold mine but being denied work and refund of fees paid. Security guards at the mining site opened fire on the rioters and allegedly killed an unspecified number of people. A dozen men fled and jumped into a 40-foot gold pit and died when a dirt wall fell on top of them. Government security has been deployed to the camp and the camp has been closed indefinitely. At least 20 dead.
A group of school-aged children protested on the grounds of the capitol building in Monrovia, demanding free education.

Police allegedly beat up civilians and a pregnant woman during eviction raids in the Public Works market on Bushrod Island. Police officers were sent to carry out evictions after court officers were allegedly attacked by marketers during an initial eviction exercise.
Marketeers of the Public Works market on Bushrod Island allegedly attacked court officers to resist eviction. Date not clear

Employees at the Liberia Agricultural Company (LAC) have staged a non-violent protest on the premises of the company, demanding that management addresses the health condition of seventeen of their colleagues who reportedly sustained injuries as a result of explosion.

Relative calm has returned to Zorzor, Lofa County following the intervention of the Liberia National Police after angry youths set ablaze two houses and several cell phones booths in the Zorzor Lutheran Church community

Several aggrieved workers of the Liberia Maritime Authority (LiMA) Beach and Waterway Project on Tuesday, March 3 protested at the Capitol Building in Monrovia in demand payment of eight months salary arrears

Scores of individuals under the banner of the Paynesville Business Association Incorporated (PABA) are accusing the City Corporation of arbitrarily hiking taxes in the municipality. The Association protested at the main entrance to the Capitol Building yesterday holding placards.

Several students of Catholic schools on March 6 demonstrated in front of the Catholic Education Secretariat in Monrovia, demanding authority of the institution to pay five-month arrears owed their teachers.

Protesting students, under the banner ""Grand Bassa University Student Union"" or GBUSU Tuesday converged on the grounds of the Capitol Building and barricaded lawmakers from the county in demand of scholarship funds to enable them return to school.

The start of the national Constitutional Review Conference in Gbarnga was Monday marred by a series of protests. Placard-wielding youths stormed the Gbarnga administration building demanding representations at the event while Christians and Muslims clashed.

The ongoing constitutional review conference in Gbarnga, Bong County was marred by protest action Tuesday when delegates complained of the omission of several proposals earmarked for deliberation. Representatives of youth and student groups who also joined the protest, chanted revolutionary slogans and sang songs which delayed the conference for several hours. The protesters accused the Constitution Review Committee (CRC) of advancing nine views instead of the 25 recurring views expressed by the people of Liberia during its nationwide consultations and meetings

Muslim Community of Bong County stormed the grounds of the Gbarnga Administrative building Wednesday morning in protest, demanding removal of count 24 of views being validated at the ongoing National Constitutional Conference. Count 24 is being proffered by a Christian group, which wants Liberia to be legislated as a Christian State

A 30-year-old physically challenged man has died, days after allegedly being flogged by a team of Action Agents of Liberia's Drugs Enforcement Agency or DEA led by a commander in Dartorken town, Tiempo District, River Gee County. The jury team that went to investigate was unable to interview people on the crime scene because the area was hostile, and protests were ongoing

Several aggrieved citizens of Giah Town, Disco Hill, Margibi County on Tuesday, April 7 blocked the only road leading to a place where Ebola bodies are buried. The citizens say the Government of Liberia owes them a balance of US$25,000 for the 25 acres of land, which they provided to the government.

A ""corroner jury"" team that went to investigate the death of a disabled man who was beaten by DEA officials was unable to interview people on the crime scene because the area was hostile, and protests were ongoing.

Students of Cestos High School in Rivercess County yesterday morning stormed the county administration building to express their anger and frustration, chanting, ""No renovation, no school, no By-Election."" According to the reports, the students broke doors, windows, chairs and other furniture in the administrative building housing the Superintendents compound. Just before the day ended, the police gained control of the crowd and managed to arrest a student who is believed to be the leader of the demonstration.

Workers of almost all of Liberias Ebola Treatment Units (ETUs) have staged a major protest in Monrovia, demanding benefits owed them by the Government of Liberia. The workers, predominantly healthcare practitioners, gathered at the seat of the Liberian legislature early Thursday morning to inform lawmakers about their over four months unpaid benefits.

A motorcyclist was killed by a soldier of the Armed Forces of Liberia following a scuffle on Tuesday in Thinker Village Community in Paynesville. Meanwhile, police have arrested the soldier and are investigating the event.

Enraged motorcyclists resorted to violence in Redlight, Paynesville yesterday in retaliation for the alleged killing of their fellow rider by a police officer. The rioting resulted in the burning down of a police substation. Several police officers reportedly sustained serious injuries and were taken to a nearby health facility.

A Liberian police officer allegedly beat a motorcyclist to death following a heated dispute between the police officer (not named) and a rider only identified as Alfred. Government claims the motorist fell from his bike when he was fleeing from Police after he allegedly assaulted one of them at the GSA Road intersection.

Seven hundred Liberian Ebola workers took to the streets of the capital Monrovia for a second day on Saturday to demand promised hazard pay. The workers hired by MSF on Saturday blocked the entrance to Liberias biggest Ebola facility.

A major check point in Kolahun District, Lofa County has been completely vandalized by some motorcyclists in defense of one of their colleagues who was said to have been flogged allegedly by an officer of the Liberia National Police (LNP) in Lofa County.
Workers of China Union in Bong Mines, Bong County went on a go-slow protest from 1st to 6th May demanding better conditions at work.
Mine workers of the G-5 group of Companies instituted a two-day peaceful strike action from Monday on the compound of the company in Kinjor, Grand Cape Mount County over payment of benefits

A group of young people, mainly women and carrying placards, blocked the main entrance of the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning in Monrovia Monday during the early morning hours and prevented people from entering and leaving the building, in demand for eight months salary arrears. Police were deployed on the scene to prevent violence which nearly ensued.

Residents of Butaw staged a protest demanding to meet a visiting senior official of the Golden Veroleum Company, which resulted to the throwing of stones and destruction of some of GVL properties. 20 people involved in the rioting were arrested by the police.

Members of the ex-ruling National Patriotic Party staged a protest on the former ruling party headquarters for about three days, in an attempt to prevent the national chairman and his team of leaders from entering the premises. The protesters are demanding that he steps down.

Members of the ex-ruling National Patriotic Party staged a protest on the former ruling party headquarters for about three days, in an attempt to prevent the national chairman and his team of leaders from entering the premises. The protesters are demanding that he steps down.
Several local business owners in Kakata, Margibi County under the banner ""Margibi Muslim Council"" mostly Fulanis closed their stores and shops over the weekend in protest to Christianizing Liberia.

Members of the ex-ruling National Patriotic Party staged a protest on the former ruling party headquarters for about three days, in an attempt to prevent the national chairman and his team of leaders from entering the premises. The protesters are demanding that he steps down.

Movement of forces: Armed men have crossed into Liberia from Ivory Coast and occupied an area of forest, spreading alarm in the remote border region, a lawmaker said on Wednesday. Date(s) of the movement not known.

More than 100 Ebola center workers stormed the Ministry of Health in eastern Monrovia on Wednesday demanding hazard pay that they said they havent received since the country was declared Ebola-free May 9 by the World Health Organization

A multitude of protesting students besieged the Presidential Convoy outside the Monrovia City Hall in Monrovia, while departing from a function Thursday. They persistently disallowed her convoy to drive through from the Monrovia City Hall resulting to her resolve to speak with them amid unending slogans. Officers of the elite Executive Protective Service peacefully pulled back the students to create an enabling environment for the President- also heavily flanked by EPS officers, riot police and UN peacekeepers as she approached her temporary office at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs

Riots broke out in River Gee where some people burnt a police station, a Liberian flag and a privately-owned transport truck, in reaction to the death of a motorcyclist, who died in an accident that occurred near Kilepo Jowroken, Chedepo District in River Gee.

Several healthcare workers who worked at the Ebola treatment units (ETU) in and around Monrovia on Monday staged another round of strikes at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in demand of hazard pay they claim the Government of Liberia owes them.

A civic group under the banner, ""Water, Sanitation and Hygiene Network on Friday staged a sit in action at the offices of the Liberia Water and Sewer Corporation (LWSC) in Monrovia, demanding concrete action to improve service, governance and financing for water, sanitation and hygiene
Press Union of Liberia notified the Liberia National Police regarding the alleged brutalization of the journalists while performing their reportorial duties in Kakata, Margibi County

Students of the Bong County Technical College and some citizens on Tuesday staged a peaceful demonstration to draw the attention of the county leadership to the perpetual delay in the completion of the colleges facilities.

Angry youths gathered on Carey Street on 16 September calling for the prosecution of a senior state security officer and his subordinates after they reportedly physically brutalized an unarmed civilian on 13 September. The angry crowd chased and chanted anti violence slogan. Darlington George was dismissed of his functions and later arrested
Hundreds of Liberians stormed the courtyard of the Capitol Building in a peaceful protest to demand changes to the ""2015 Liberia Electricity Act"" last week passed by the Liberian Senate.

The Muslim community dominated by the Mandingo ethnic groups has disrupted a team of surveyors backed by the 8th Judiciary Circuit Court Sheriff over surveying of a land. The Surveyors went to the Police Station for rescue on ground that angry Muslim youths obstructed the court order to survey the disputed land.

violent demonstration carried out on 28 September by some individuals who claimed that they were hired and worked at various Ebola treatment units (ETUs) but have not been paid by the Liberian Government.

column9: UNMIL: United Nations Mission in Liberia (2003-)
column16: Liberia News Agency; Liberian Observer; New Dawn
column17: Violent demonstration led to burning and looting of properties and thousands of dollars after the arrest of the murderes of a man for ritualistic purposes. Several security offices, including the Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) sub-office in Ganta, were looted during the violence. The arrival of police and UNMIL forces did not deter the rioters. A 3-day curfew was imposed on the county. 47 people were arraigned in connection with the riots
A man accused of ritually beheading a motorcyclist is killed by a mob during riots in Ganta.

Eight traditional ""Bushmasters"" besieged Jungle Jean Village in Fuamah District, Bong County in protest against the desecration of the Poro and Sande societies by a pastor in his sermon. The incident led to the closure of all businesses in the area and forced people to stay indoors with no one allowed to enter the town. No reports of violence.

Eight traditional ""Bushmasters"" besieged Jungle Jean Village in Fuamah District, Bong County in protest against the desecration of the Poro and Sande societies by a pastor in his sermon. The incident led to the closure of all businesses in the area and forced people to stay indoors with no one allowed to enter the town. No reports of violence.
Police flog and abuse some of individuals accused of taking part in rioting and vigilante violence in Ganta.

Former Ebola Treatment Unit workers protested against governments inaction regarding hazard payment when President Sirleaf was to deliver a special Hand Washing Day message at the William V. S. Tubman High School in Sinkor. riot police officers from the Police Support Unit or PSU of the Liberia National Police were immediately called to move the rioters across the street but the protesters remain adamant. Situation remained peaceful
Students from the Student Unification Party (SUP) disrupted classes on Fendell campus to protest against Student Alvin Wessehs expulsion

Students at the Robertsport High School in Grand Cape Mount County staged a violent protest against their parents decision to underwrite the salaries of six teachers assigned to the school. Some buildings were looted and important documents taken by the demonstrators. Members of the joint security were called in to calm the situation.

About 45,000 residents, particularly squatters from the Industrial Park in Gardnersville have staged street protests in front of the UNMIL office in Sinkor against a planned demolition on 26 October by the Ministry of Public Works.

A multitude of protesters from the Worwee Community (Montserrado County District #8) gathered near the Ministry of Foreign Affairs after resisting an eviction order on 17 October and defying a Supreme Court ruling that grants 48 acres of land to a former lawmaker, Jesse C. Payne.

column16: New Dawn; New Republic Liberia; Front Page Africa
column17: Tens of thousands of students of the University of Liberia stormed its two campuses in demand of the reinstatement of one of their colleagues, Student Alvin Wesseh who has been expelled. They first staged a sit-in at the main street leading to the Fendell Campus until riot officers from the PSU were deployed in battle ready positions to ease tensions.

column16: Front Page Africa; New Dawn; New Republic Liberia
column17: Tens of thousands of students of the University of Liberia stormed its two campuses in demand of the reinstatement of one of their colleagues, Student Alvin Wesseh who has been expelled. After roadblocking the Fendell Campus, they marched to the Monrovia campus. Riot officers from the PSU were deployed in battle ready positions, and were later reinforced. Angry students began throwing stones into the university compound and also on the main street. students accused the Police of throwing stones from within the university fence
Placards carrying Liberia Marketing Association (LMA) members marched on the Capitol Building to protest the alleged seizure of a land

Protesters allegedly disrupted a meeting attended by Montserrado County District # 8 Representative, Acarious Gray, on grounds that they were not informed about the forum. They allegedly stoned his official vehicle as he left the meeting and assaulted one of his security guards. At least seven defendants from the district are facing multiple charges of rioting, aggravated assault, criminal mischief and disorderly conduct in connection with the incident

column7: AGWC: Aggrieved Group of Weala Community; Women (Liberia)
column17: Over 300 women from the ""Aggrieved Group of Weala Community"" staged a peaceful sit-in against the Chinese International Construction Company or CICO implementing rehabilitation work. They barricaded the two main entrances to the companies premises in demand of benefits for damages of their houses caused by daily earth blasting operations.

Violent confrontation ensued between residents of Jallah Town Community and the newly established Presidential Taskforce, over the manner in which residents properties were demolished by the Taskforce. Riot police of the Emergency Response Unit or ERU and Police Support Unit or PSU subsided the violence.

column6: Military Forces of Liberia (2006-2018) Presidential Guard
column17: The head of the Special Presidential Task Force allegedly beat a 13 year old child prostitute fifty lashes and handcuffed two others

Students continued to protest at the Fendell Campus of the University of Liberia, calling for the resignation of the Dean for Students Affairs. The students are advocating for the reinstatement of student Alvin Wesseh

column9: SWAL: Sports Writers Association of Liberia; Journalists (Liberia)
column17: The president and other members of the Sports Writers Association of Liberia, SWAL were assaulted by an officer of the ERU, causing them serious injuries.

An angry mob set ablaze a vehicle carrying Sinoe County Rep. Jeremiah McCaulys son and his girlfriend, after residents suspected that she was being kidnapped for ritualistic purposes. Six suspects were arrested

Residents around the Bethesda-VOA Community along the Robertsfiled Highway in Paynesville, outside Monrovia set up road blocks and burnt a facilty and vehicle following the discovery of two children's murdered bodies. The police was deployed to calm further violence

column6: UNMIL: United Nations Mission in Liberia (2003-)
column17: Two soldiers of the United Nations Mission in Liberia (UNMIL) allegedly beat a teenage boy in Bong County on 4 December.

Members and loyalists of the Presidential Task Force to demolish structures across Monrovia have protested outside the fence of the Temple of Justice on Capitol Hill just few hours before the Supreme Court of Liberia could hear a scheduled conference into a petition filed against the task forces operations. They were guarded by police forces. No direct interaction mentioned.

Supporters of former National Port Authority (NPA) Managing Director Matilda Parker protested at the Temple of Justice during jury selection process in criminal facilitation case; Parker was recently dismissed by President Sirleaf

column7: WIPNET: Women in Peace-building Network; Women (Liberia)
column17: Hundreds of women led by a local women group, Women in Peace-building Network (WIPNET) took to the streets in Monrovia carrying images of child victims, to protest against the troubling increase in rape, mob violence, mysterious deaths, and armed robbery in the past month

Supporters of former National Port Authority (NPA) Managing Director Matilda Parker protested at the Temple of Justice during jury selection process in criminal facilitation case; Parker was recently dismissed by President Sirleaf

Residents of Belema and Sawmill communities on Bushrod Island in Monrovia staged a peaceful protest on 28 December at the main entrance of the Liberia Cement Company (CEMENCO) to urge it to carry out environmental safety procedures for its ongoing demolition exercises.

Several people protested that the Government pays them for their alleged destroyed structures within the Battle Field community. They blocked the flow of vehicles on Lynch Street in Monrovia, causing the police to intervene. Protesters however continued their action. Several were arrested.
About one hundred former Ebola workers yesterday staged a peaceful demonstration in front of the Ministry of Health in Monrovia.
Protesters stormed a court last Thursday in protest. However, no one was physically attacked and no property damaged during the hours-long protest

column8: Military Forces of Liberia (2006-2018) Presidential Guard
column17: Clashes took place between the Liberian National Police and the Executive Protection Service (the official title of the Presidential Guard) after a police vehicle intrudes into the Presidential Convoy. The clash results in a few security personnel going to hospital with minor injuries.
Over 400 residents of Weala gathered at the offices of a Chinese firm in a peaceful protest demanding reparation for the demolition of their homes.

Protesting University of Liberia students from opposing campus-based parties booed and threw stones at House Speaker Alex Tyler who had come to engage with students on the main campus, disbursing the crowd

Several residents of Capitol Bypass Community took to the streets to protest their planned eviction from lands owned by Jesse Payne. They set up road blocks, threw stones and prevented vehicles from using the Bypass to access central Monrovia.The situation was brought under control with the deployment and intervention of officers of the Police Support Unit (PSU) of the Liberia National Police (LNP).

Three officers of the police Emergency Response Unit fired several arbitrary shots during a dispute at Bright Farms rubber plantation in Mount Barclay, leaving one employee killed. The three officers were dismissed and charged with manslaughter by the magisterial court. They were released on bail, and their cases were submitted to the Montserrado County court for prosecution. The prosecution dismissed charges in October, and the officers were subsequently reinstated.

A peaceful sit-in on the grounds of the Temple of Justice on Capitol Hill in Monrovia calling for the release of youth political activist Vandalark Patricks turned into a riot as some individuals engaged the police by throwing stones. Several vehicles were damaged and police threw teargas at protesters in a bid to curb the protest. At least one protester was arrested.

Partisans of main opposition Congress for Democratic Change or CDC protested at the National Police Headquarters in support of their political leader Weah who had accompanied his party vice chair Morlu to face police inquiry.
An angry mob attacked an armed robber in Bong. He later died of his wounds.
Motorcyclists from the Fiamah community protested against police brutality at the headquarters of the Liberia National Police, marching to Capitol Hill.
Members of the Cocopa Workers Union barricaded the road leading to the Cocopa Rubber Plantation in Nimba County, obstructing free movement, to protest against salary arrears.

column7: COAWU: Cocopa Agriculture Workers Union; Labour Group (Liberia)
column17: Members of the Cocopa Workers Union barricaded the main entry to the Cocopa Rubber Plantation in Nimba County, obstructing free movement, to protest against salary arrears. Police intervened to disperse the protesters.

A group of residents at Sime Darby plantation went on demonstration at the plantation and destroyed several properties belonging to the company over the disappearance of one relative. Police intervened to restore calm and arrested five people in connection with the riot.

University of Liberia students staged a peaceful protest in front of the Foreign Ministry to draw President Ellen Johnson Sirleafs attention to the increment in fees at the University, which they claim aims to deny struggling students from pursuing tertiary education.

column16: Front Page Africa; New Republic Liberia
column17: University of Liberia students gathered at the entrance of the Legislature in Monrovia to protest against a proposal to increase tuition fees. Police intervened to calm the angered students.
Police fired tear gas to disperse protesting students at the headquarters of the Liberian National Student Union calling on their President to resign, leaving one wounded.
Students of the Bong County Community College staged a peaceful protest in Gbarnga to call on Liberias President to speed up the construction of the College that started years ago.

University of Liberia students tore down schedules on the main campus to prevent the registration process at the University, in line with their previous protests against a decision to increase tuition fees. Two students sustained injuries when they engaged with the police.

An unknown number (coded as 3) of people are feared injured or dead following alleged clashes between members of the traditional Poro or Sande Societies in Grand Bassa County, mainly in Kpokon. Several houses were burnt down in the clashes.
River Gee county allegedly saw armed men from neighboring Ivory Coast carry out border attacks on several occasions. At least one person was shot in these attacks.

In May a police patrol officer reportedly beat a suspect while in custody and the detainee later died from his injuries. The officer was suspended for one month. An investigation of the incident concluded that there might have been other causes of the suspect's injuries.

Police used teargas and pepper spray to disperse hundreds of protesters that had staged a sit-in at the Margibi County office of the Chinese International Construction Company in Weala in demand of compensation for damaging their houses as a result of its operations, leaving at least four protestors seriously wounded.

A traditional secret society priest joined aggrived workers protests at the Margibi County office of the Chinese International Construction Company in Weala in demand of compensation for damaging their houses as a result of the companies operations, forcing the company to shut down its activities for the day.

Youth for Progressive Action members staged a protest at the Capitol building in Monrovia to call for immediate action against some members of the national legislature linked to allegations of bribery.

A group of alleged Unity Party (UP) supporters nearly clashed with members of the Police Support Unit (PSU) over their attempt to arrest Grand Cape Mount County Senator Varney Sherman as he was implicated in a corruption scandal. They barricaded the entrance to his house, preventing execution of the arrest and search warrants.

A group of young people gathered at the Criminal Court to show their support to House Speaker Alex Tyler after he turned himself in for his alleged involvement in a corruption scandal, chanting slogans. Disagreements led to fist fights and damaging of property.

column16: Front Page Africa; Liberia News Agency; Liberian Observer
column17: Over 400 students of the University of Liberia (UL) forcibly entered the premises of the Capitol Building to protest against inaction over tuition increase and increment of ULs allotment. They threw stones as police attempted to disperse them. 6 students were later arrested by police, and are facing multiple charges, including criminal mischief, rioting, and disorderly conduct.

The youth wing of the Congress for Democratic Change (CDC) staged a three-day hunger strike in front of the US Embassy in Monrovia to call for a stronger response to recent corruption charges faced by government officials.

Trade unions under the leadership of Public Services International (PSI) protested in Monrovia to call on the Liberian government to respect and protect workers rights across the country. The protest coincided with the 2016 International Labor Conference convened in Geneva, Switzerland.

Street vendors at Red Light in Paynesville clashed with police officers after the police issued an order requiring them to move from the main thoroughfare. Officers allegedly destroyed market stalls and exchanged verbal skirmishes with the vendors. The next day, some of the traders vandalized vehicles and damaged property worth L$100,000 of goods. When the police intervened, they threw objects at them to prevent them from making arrests.

Street vendors at Red Light in Paynesville clashed with police officers after the police issued an order requiring them to move from the main thoroughfare. Officers allegedly destroyed market stalls and exchanged verbal skirmishes with the vendors. The next day, some of the traders vandalized vehicles and damaged property worth L$100,000 of goods. When the police intervened, they threw objects at them to prevent them from making arrests.

More than a hundred students at the J. W. Person Elementary School on Clay Street in Monrovia protested against the prolonged closure of their school by the owner over rental arrears by the government.
Several persons with disabilities staged a peaceful demonstration at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to protest against their isolation within government affairs.
Street vendors in Monrovia protested against mal-handling of some of their colleagues by City Police enforcing regulation barring selling in the main streets.

Nearly 200 parking attendants from the Monrovia City Cooperation protested in the capital, calling on government officials to halt the awarding of a contract to a corporation, which would render them jobless.
Police allegedly beat and used tear gas on a civilian in Darsaw Town, in the context of an operation to prevent witchcraft activities in Rivercess county.
Teachers who were left out of a national partnership school programme staged a small protest at a graduation ceremony in Kakata.

Police used teargas to disperse an angry mob in the Congo Town Back Road community who attacked a car with two policemen in plain clothes during a Police operation meant to arrest drug dealers. Three policemen were injured by the residents.

Cocopa Plantation workers in Nimba County set up new roadbloacks on the main highway linking Ganta and Saclepea with the southeastern region in demand of salary arrears from the past four months, threatening to take action against anyone trying to make his way through the roadblock. Some managers houses were also allegedly burglarised in the days leading to the protest. The House of Representatives called for action by the plantation on the issue a few days later.
A group of All Liberian Party supporters and officials allegedly attacked several health workers and staffers, including guards at the Ganta United Methodist Hospital in Ganta City, Nimba County.

Residents of the Redemption Road community in Monrovia set up roadblocks to demand the removal of a dead body on the beach, paralysing traffic. A member of police convinced them to remove the roadblock.

Weala and surrounding residents barricaded the offices of the County Superintendent in Kakata, renewing their demands for reparation from the Chinese International Construction Company (CICO) for damages to their properties.

column7: NTAL: National Teachers Association of Liberia; MCSSTA: Monrovia Consolidated School System Teachers Association
column17: Members of the National Teachers Association of Liberia (NTAL), of the Monrovia Consolidated School System Teachers Association, and of other local teachers' unions staged a sit-in protest at the Ministry of Education in Monrovia, beginning a strike action against the refusal of the President to dismiss two officials accused of hampering reforms to the countries education system. A week later, President Sirleaf ordered the dismissal of protesting teachers.
A police officer pepper-sprayed, beat and arrested a sheriff at the Monrovia Temple of Justice as he was returning from an operation in Nimba county following an alleged verbal altercation.

Students in Kakata, Margibi county, took the streets to protest their teachers absence in school as they were participating in protests in Monrovia demanding the resignation of Education Minister Werner. Students set up roadblocks preventing traffic on the main highway leading to Gbarnga, Bong County and to Monrovia, and allegedly ransacked several public buildings. They ended the protest with the intervention of county officials. President Sirleaf ordered the dismissal of protesting teachers and vowed to deal with the protesting students as well.

Students in Unification Town (Smell-No-Taste) in Harbel, Margibi County, took the streets to protest their teachers absence in school as they were participating in protests in Monrovia demanding the resignation of Education Minister Werner. Students set up roadblocks, preventing traffic on the main roads. President Sirleaf ordered the dismissal of protesting teachers and vowed to deal with the protesting students as well.

All Liberian People Party (ALP) youth supporters besieged the compound of Radio Gbarnga in Bong County demanding their parties former Chairman - who was speaking on the radio show that morning - to restitute identification card fees they had paid a year prior. Some of the rioters attempted to throw stones at the stations premises to raise attention while others asked the station to discontinue their program, forcing the the station to cut off. Lomax was on the show to officially announce his defection to the Liberty Party.
Police arrested a women during a raid, and stripped and beat her severely in October.

column7: NAHWAL: National Health Workers Association of Liberia; RIAWU: Roberts International Airport Workers Union
column17: A group of trade union members peacefully stormed offices of the Civil Service Agency (CSA) in Central Monrovia to protest the dismissal of leaders of the Health Workers Association of Liberia (NAHWAL) and of the Roberts International Airport Workers Union (RIAWU).
Morris Farm community members in Montserrado killed an alleged robber after a series of armed robberies that left several people injured.
Looting: Unidentified group burnt down, looted and destroyed property in Ganta.

Concerned NPP supporters led by Yekeh Kolubah stormed the NPP headquarters in Monrovia protesting lack of consultation in the merging of the party with a coalition of other parties. Security guards on duty at the premises reportedly resorted to cutlasses, stakes and other available weapons to prevent them from entering the compound. No reports of injuries or vandalism.

A group of men attacked a police officer enforcing a 10pm traffic ban against motorcyclists in Brewerville in Montserrado county, leaving him severely injured and his vehicle damaged. Five suspected were later arrested by police, including the community chairman who is suspected to have ordered the attack.

Angry mob attacked a police officer as he was arresting a man who had earlier murdered a community member in Weala, Margibi county, breaking the officers leg and stoning the victim nearly to death. Police arrested several people in relations to the incident.
Suspected angry mob killed a man in Kakata in Margibi county.
Angry mob assaulted a man at Elwa junction in Monrovia, leaving him severely injured.

column7: JACC: Joint Action Committee on Children
column17: Children under the banner of the ""Joint Action Committee on Children"" staged a march in Monrovia to denounce frequent violence and injustices targeting them and to remember to children found killed in 2015 whose bodies have been kept by police. They presented the Liberia National Police several recommendations.

Clash between Congress for Democratic Coalition (CDC) supporters and militants at the sub-partys office in Paynesville City during a petitioning ceremony for an incumbent Montserrado County Representative. After the clash, one of the groups severely beat a journalist attempting to provide coverage of the fight, damaging his material and stealing property.

Clash between Congress for Democratic Coalition (CDC) supporters and militants at the sub-partys office in Paynesville City during a petitioning ceremony for an incumbent Montserrado County Representative. After the clash, one of the groups severely beat a journalist attempting to provide coverage of the fight, damaging his material and stealing property.
Liberians working on an ExxonMobil exploration ship protested over employment of foreign nationals to replace them.

Thousands of Liberians predominantly marketers took to the streets in Monrovia to protest the rapid tax increases on import goods and services, which has led to sky rocket prices on local markets. Police intervened to disperse the protesters using teargas, leaving one person reportedly injured. The protesters vowed to continue their protest through a week-long strike action unless authorities revised tax levels.

column7: PNAMOB: Patriotic Nimbaian Movement for Boakai; Women (Liberia)
column17: Thousands of women led by the Patriotic Nimbaian Movement for Boakai (PNAMOB) marched in Ganta City to promote voter registration for the 2017 elections.
Vigilante militia beat a man after attending a church service in Duala over wrongly alleged stealing, leaving him severely injured.

Around 3,000 angry residents ransacked a bar and attempted to break through the Liberian government hospital by throwing stones in Buchanan, Grand Bassa county, after the mysterious death of a girl and protesting the lack of response by police to the event. Police dispersed them at the hospital and later arrested 20 in connection with the riot.

Students at the Bong County Technical College in Gbarnga staged a peaceful protest to demand a new administration at the college, the return of the dismissed student president and better learning equipment.

column16: Front Page Africa; New Republic Liberia
column17: Students from a public school in Monrovia demonstrated over delayed payment of their teachers' salaries by the school administration, which has led to some of the teachers not attending classes. On the same day, subscribers of a cell company protested at the company's sub office in Monrovia over halt of free call.

Public service workers stormed the head offices of the Independent National Commission on Human Rights (INCHR) to protest bad labor practices implemented by the government, particularly the introduction of two labor laws denying them the rights to organise into unions.

column16: Front Page Africa; Liberian Observer; New Dawn
column17: Marketers and local business owners led by the Patriotic Entrepreneurs of Liberia (PATEL) closed their shops and staged rallies over three days from 31 January in and around Monrovia to protest tax and tariff legislation as well as police harassment of traders. In Paynesville, some arrests and confiscation of goods by police were reported. At the end of the three days, PATEL threatened wider actions the following week if authorities did not respond to their calls.
A mob killed a suspected criminal in the People Street Community in Gbarnga in Bong county.

column16: Front Page Africa; Liberian Observer; New Dawn
column17: Marketers and local business owners led by the Patriotic Entrepreneurs of Liberia (PATEL) closed their shops and staged rallies over three days from 31 January in and around Monrovia to protest tax and tariff legislation as well as police harassment of traders. In Paynesville, some arrests and confiscation of goods by police were reported. At the end of the three days, PATEL threatened wider actions the following week if authorities did not respond to their calls.

column16: Front Page Africa; Liberian Observer; New Dawn
column17: Marketers and local business owners led by the Patriotic Entrepreneurs of Liberia (PATEL) closed their shops and staged rallies over three days from 31 January in and around Monrovia to protest tax and tariff legislation as well as police harassment of traders. In Paynesville, some arrests and confiscation of goods by police were reported. At the end of the three days, PATEL threatened wider actions the following week if authorities did not respond to their calls.

Members of the Manos ethnic clan fired gunshots to threaten and disperse a team of suveyors backed by police officers who had come to enforce a survey order on a disputed land between Sokopa and Ganwee towns. Clashes ensued between them and the rival Mandingo clan the following week.

Students of the main public high school in District #3 in Grand Bassa County on Monday morning protested the lack of major subject instructors in their classrooms ahead of their semester exams, ""bullying"" the district education officer and storming the district's administration building.
A mob killed a suspected criminal in the Fareast Community of Bong county.

Clashes between Mandingo and Manos communities from Sokopa Township over a disputed parcel of land that the Mandigos wanted to survey left at least one person injured and another missing. Sokopa and its surroundings were deserted after the gunfire.
Residents of Weala protested against the transporting of 200 persons to register at two of the registration centres in the town, on the grounds that they were not from the district.

Clashes between members of the Krahn and Gio (Dan) ethnic groups in Youkorway, Kparblee district of Nimba led to the drawing of a battle-line between Yourkorway New and Old towns and to a complete breakdown of social and economic activities between the towns. A peace committee reconcilied the two communities end February.

Workers at the Unity Conference Center Ebola Treatment Unit in Virginia, Montserrado County, staged a protest in demand of salaries for November and December 2014, which authorities had committed to pay early January.

Hundreds of students of the Monrovia Consolidated School System (MCSS) staged a march calling for the reinstatement of dismissed MCSS instructors. A Deputy Police Inspector intervened to take student leaders to the Education Minister's office.
A mob severely beat and injured a former police officer accused of committing robberies at New Kru Town.
A mob killed a suspected criminal in David Dean Town, popularly known as Gold Camp in Kokoyah Statutory District, Bong county.

Fist fight between a registrant and a supervisor during a voter registration exercise in Panyesville, as the supervisor refused to allow him to register as he had arrived outside working hours. The registrant was heavily injured. Police later arrested the supervisor.

column8: Police Forces of Liberia (2006-2018) Prison Guards
column17: 21 prisoners escaped from Gbarnga central prison compound in Bong County after a clash with prison guards that left at least one of them injured. A brief curfew was subsequently imposed in the area.
A man was mobbed to death by an angry crowd in Pleebo Sodoken Statutory District of Maryland County after he was accused of attempting to kidnap a baby for ritualistic purpose.

Clash between soldiers and police officers at the Soul Clinic Police Depot in Paynesville left two police officers injured. A civilian was also injured and robbed in the scuffle. Officers reportedly clashed over a military uniform.

mob violence at the Sapo National Park in Sinoe County over the weekend reportedly resulted in the deaths of two forest rangers working with the Forestry Development Authority (FDA).Police confirmed the deaths of the two rangers, and said they were killed while responding to an upheaval at the park. A team of police investigators have been dispatched to the crime scene to probe the situation.
the Concerned Citizens to Protect the Constitution (CCPC) led a peaceful protest demanding that the National Election Commission (NEC) boss should resign on suspicion that he has dual citizenship

15 students from privately run United Methodist University or UMU on Ashmum Street in Monrovia have been charged on multiple accounts and sent to court for allegedly obstructing government function through a violent riot and wounding four officers of the Liberia National Police

Liberian Women Protest for Passage of Domestic Violence Bill. On Tuesday, women and men dressed in black attire gathered with placards with inscriptions ""Love is life free of violence"", ""Domestic violence is a long-term harm to the victims"", ""Children our future, please protect them from domestic violence.""The Gender Coordinator at the Gender Ministry, Deddeh Kwekwe, said the protest was intended to draw the attention of the lawmakers to the importance of passing the bill.

Six civilians, including a pregnant woman, sustained multiple injuries when they were assaulted by some members of the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) assigned at the Camp Tubman Military Barracks in Gbarnga. The case is being investigated.

Machete-waving citizens of Yookudi town in Harper District, Maryland County have violently destroyed several properties, including houses in a dispute over 260.3 acres of land situated along the Harper Prollo border.

Child Righs Activist led a group of his supporters to the Capitol Building demanding Grand Gedeh District 2 Representative, Morais Waylee, to resign and exonerate himself from an allegation that he raped his 13 year-old niece. The Monrovia City Court has ordered the arrest of child rights activist and a few of his followers
40 health science students of the community college protested with placards, calling on the administration and government to grant the department accreditation to graduate its students.

The main street in Clara Town was filled by youth protesters who carried placards, burricading roads, and chanted against the vice president's visit and complained that the government has not made efforts to eradicate poverty. The Liberia National Police restrained protesters from causing any damage to the vice president's convoy.
Passengers who travel from Buchanan to Sinoe and Grand Kru Counties set up a road block at the main Buchanan-Monrovia highway junction, to protest police harassment.
Safe-citites Women Forum in collaboration with Action Aid Liberia, protested the rape of a 13 year old girl, holding several placards .
Members of the opposition Coalition for Democratic Change (CDC) reported that one of the political parties' campaign banners bearing the image of Senator George Weah was torn by unknown persons.
Dozens of supporters of opposition Movement for Economic Empowerment (MOVEE) of Dr. Mills Jones attacked and flogged a man

The director general of the General Services Agency (GSA) on escaped assault at the Temple of Justice when she was confronted by a violent group of protesters angered at the omission of her name from an assault charge. No injury reported.
Looting: Unknown elements have reportedly looted the local offices of opposition United Peoples' Party (UPP) in Montserrado County District #15.

A group of youth stormed the court compound on Tuesday morning with placards and preventd vehicles from entering the court yard. The group was in protest of the court's decision to drop criminal charges against former mayor of Monrovia. Seven protesters were arrested, and released on September 7th.

Supporters of the Liberty Party (LP) and the Coalition for Democratic Change (CDC) violently clashed on Wednesday, 20 September, leaving at least two persons reportedly wounded, in t campaign violence ahead of the October 10th Presidential and Representatives Elections.
20 September. A clash between supporters of CDC and Liberty party in Sanniquellie resulted in one injury
21 September. Supporters of CDC and Unity Party clashed in Paynesville over the legislative seat in the constituency. Minor injuries reported
On 03 October, employees of the Monrovia City Corporation (MCC) protested the poor working conditions, benefits and salary increment. The employees held placards on the ground of the MCC.
On 10 October, hundreds of women from various women and youth groups of Liberia took to the streets of Monrovia in protest of the rape amendment bill recently by the Senate.
On 10 October, voters bocked roads to protest their names missing on the voters roll in Bong. Police restored calm.

Tension has brewed at the Grand Bassa County Community College (GBCCC) where Students Monday staged a peaceful protest that brought activities at the institution to a standstill. The protest is in response to disenchantments ranging from the lack of ID cards for three semesters, lack of PE shirts, handbooks, insurance, effective transportation service and the reconditioning of the bridge connecting Four Houses Community and the GBCCc Paynesberry Campus.

The College of Engineering and Technology at the William V.S. Tubman University in Maryland County, southeast Liberia, risks closure for a semester to enable administration to address concerns of protesting students of the college. Protests by students have disrupted normal academic activities at the University, including ongoing midterm examinations.

Controversial talkshow host Henry Costa was allegedly attacked by some CDC supporters on Mechlin Street after reportedly raining invectives at the political leader of the Coalition for Democratic Change (CDC), Senator George Weah.

Scores of angry men besieged the main entrance to the compound of the state broadcaster, Liberia Broadcasting System (LBS), blocking the main thoroughfare leading to the commercial district of Red-Light. The local area youth were demanding justice for their friend who was allegedly killed by an officer of the Liberia National Police (LNP).

A man was allegedly killed by an officer of the Liberia National Police (LNP). He was alleged to have been brutalized to death by the new head of the Zone 5 Police Depot located in the commercial district of Red Light.
Property destruction: Associate Justice Sie - A - Nyene Yuoh's residence was attacked by unidentified men.

Students and riot officers of the Liberian National Police clashed on the Fendell Campus of the University of Liberia. The riot began when thousands of students were reportedly denied by authorities of the university to complete their registration process.

Riot officers at the LNP raided protesters at UL on Monday during protest over the closure of registration process for the ongoing academic semester, arresting both prospective graduates and non- graduating students, with the protesters throwing objects at the campus-based police officers unequipped to withstand the level of violence.
