A group of women under the banner Movement for the Removal of the National Election Commission Chairman Cllr. Jerome Korkoya staged a peaceful protest at the headquarter of the National Elections Commission (NEC) calling for President Ellen Johnson - Sirleaf to ensure the removal of Chairman Korkoya from the Commission and the full implementation of the Supreme Court ruling and mandate before the runoff election is conducted

Some partisans of oppositions Liberty Party (LP) of Cllr. Charles Walker Brumskine and Coalition for Democratic Change (CDC) of Sen. George Manneh Weah clashed at the headquarters of LP. The clash ensued when officials of the two parties agreed to start an endorsement program at LP's headquarters in Congo Town, suburb of Monrovia and later march to the CDC headquarters which is also in Congo Town as a public show of solidarity

No death was reported from the attack on a depot of the Liberia National Police (LNP) in Coca-Cola Community. The gunmen asked about the whereabouts of the commander of the Coca-Cola Community police depot, while holding hostage some of the officers on duty on the day of the attack.

Hundreds of young men and women flooded the CDC headquarters on Monday and Tuesday of this week. Many of them believed they'll be paid a minimum of US$10 per day times the number of days for the temporary job the party offered them.

Hundreds of young men and women flooded the CDC headquarters on Monday and Tuesday of this week. Many of them believed they'll be paid a minimum of US$10 per day times the number of days for the temporary job the party offered them.
Wives of soldiers of the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), blocked highway leading to the Roberts International Airport (RIA) to demand their late husbands benefits.
Widows of deceased soldiers stormed the Capitol Hill Foreign Ministry Affairs offices of President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf to also demand their late husbands benefits.
Armed police officers of the Emergency Response Unit (ERU) are said to have violently dispersed a group of protesting students at Sime Darby Oil Palm Plantation in Grand Cape Mount and Bomi counties
Armed police officers of the Emergency Response Unit (ERU) are said to have violently dispersed a group of protesting students at Sime Darby Oil Palm Plantation in Grand Cape Mount and Bomi counties.

Students of the University of Liberia barricaded their president, Dr. Ophelia Inez Weeks, in the auditorium of the Capitol Hill campus for nearly seven hours for ignoring their call to let the registration process continue.

At least 31 retirees of the Liberia Revenue Authority yesterday staged a protest in demand of their retirement benefits at the headquarters of the LRA. The demonstration was sparked by what the group termed as management's refusal to pay their retirement benefits.

""Thugs"" converged on the UP headquarters to stage a protest against the expulsion of President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf and few other party members. The protesting group had come to read a statement debunking the expulsions but met stiff resistance from security officers and other partisans on ground.

Some PAC youth recently staged a protest against Sime Darby's management in demand of school buses to transport students.The protest, which lasted for several hours, brought normal working activities at the company' head office to a standstill. It was eventually brought under control by officers of the Liberia National Police (LNP).

Arrests: Officers of the Emergency Response Unit (ERU) of the Liberia National Police backed by some security guards at Salala Rubber Corporation (SRC) allegedly raided several towns and villages near SRC, arresting and detaining many persons. According to some villagers, it is in retaliation to a mask dancer's protest against series of killings at SRC 'Camp 8' and Bonolon Town.

Two men are said to have reportedly gone missing from former Finance Minister David Farhat's farm following a tussle over a piece of land with another group that is said to be claiming the land in the Mount Barclay area in Montserrado County.

Contractors' from the Jiangsu Provincial Construction Group Company setup a roadblock to demand their back pay. The Chinese engineering firm is constructing Liberia's ministerial complex in Congo Town which is a US$40 million project funded by the People's Republic of China.

Angry mob of Patient Shop Community in Gardnersville Township a Monrovia suburb has flogged a suspected criminal to death. Residents described the deceased as one of many criminals, who had terrorized inhabitants of Patient Shop community, Yanford Town, and adjacent communities, respectively.

In Montserrado County Electoral District#15, angry residents demanding power for the township held officers of the Police Support Unit or PSU in a standoff. What began as a peaceful protest subsequently degenerated to stone throwing and tear gas battle between residents and the police.
Citizens at Sime Darby Liberia Plantation in Bomi County embarked on a protest last week after a man went missing after his arrest by the company's security. The protest led to some property damages.
On 16 April, angry residents of Caldwell Township in Montserrado county mob to death a notorious armed robber.
On 15 May, students from Cuttington Universty in Gbarnga, set road blocks on the highway to protest the absence of the lecturers in classes.
On 24 May, angry commercial motocyclists clashed with police in a stone throwing battle, as one of their colleagues was killed by police earlier this months. Three wounded.
On 14 June, marketers from the Ganta General Market in Ganta, Nimba County staged a street protest calling on President Weah to address the escalating exchange rate.
On 14 June, clashes between protesters and police erupted in Zofor, Lofa, as people set up roadblocks demanding officers to turn in a killer.

On the week of 2 July, students hurled stones at other students during the Student Democratic Alliance (STUDA)'s anniversary celebrations at the Capitol Hill campus of the University of Liberia. Some injured and property vandalised.
On 6 August, taxi drivers protested the reduction in transport fares in Paynesville, Monrovia. They set up road blocks and were dispersed by police forces.

On August 24th, protesters gathered in Brewersville (Montserrado) to demonstrate against the apparent refusal of the police to charge a murder suspect. Subsequent reports indicate that the suspect (who was accused of murdering and dismembering his foster son) was released without charge. 14 police officers have been suspended over the incident, and authorities have pledged to re-arrest the suspect.

On September 10th, former government employees working for the Special Presidential Taskforce (tracking down stolen vehicles) protested at the Ministry of Foreign Affair in Monrovia over the government's failure to pay the workers for their labour. The government had cancelled their contracts early, apparently without renumerating them.
On 17 September, hundreds of Liberians took the streets of the capital Monrovia to demonstrate over the disappearance of newly printed bills worth nearly $100 million.
On September 24th, people protested in Monrovia over a large shipment of Liberian banknotes (worth approx US $100 million) which had supposedly gone missing.

On October 1st, hundreds of protesters gathered in Monrovia to demonstrate against a missing shipment of banknotes. On October 3rd, the Liberian central bank claimed that the money was not missing, and labelled media reports erroneous.
On October 8th, protesters gathered outside the office of the President in Monrovia, to demonstrate against the removal of the head of the Liberia Marketing Association.
On October 18th, protesters (who were mainly female) gathered in Monrovia to protest against alleged sexual abuse that took place in schools administered by the More Than Me charity.
On October 23rd, protesters in Monrovia marched in support of the head of a school which has become embroiled in a major scandal.

On October 27th, squatters clashed with police at Bassa Town (Montserrado), who were attempting to evict the residents of a property they had been ordered to leave. Either 12 or 15 police were injured (two figures are provided in the source) after residents threw stones at the police, who fled the scene, reportedly abandoning all of their equipment.

On November 5th, a mob formed vandalised the installations of a Turkish mining company base in Gbarnga (Bong county) after a vehicle belonging to a Chinese sub-contractor of the company hit and killed four people in Sayeweh Town. 52 people have been arrested by police.

On 12 November 2018, protesters marched through Monrovia, in a journey which ended at the US embassy. The demonstrators were calling for the establishment of a war and economic crimes commission, to investigate injustices dating back from the civil war. [size=no report].
On 12 November 2018 (on or around), protesters blocked roads in the Jallah Town neighbourhood of Monrovia, in protest at the lack of electricity over the previous three weeks. [size=no report].

On November 17th, supporters of the CDC and Unity Party clashed in Monrovia, causing several injuries. The incident occurred shortly before a by-election is scheduled to take place in District 13 (close to the capital).

On November 26th, drivers protesting an increase in vehicle registration fees reportedly set up roadblocks at various points in and around Bong county (coordinates for Gbarnga, Bong, used). Police dispersed the drivers with tear gas, injuring a nine year old girl in the process.
On December 3rd, demonstrators blocked roads with burning tires at Caldwell (Monrovia), in protest at the lack of electricity in the neighbourhood. Police dispersed the demonstrators with tear gas.
03 January. Protesters in Marshall Town of Margibi demonstrate against the release of four people on land dispute charges.
07 January. Students protest in Congo Town of Monrovia against the construction of a wall blocking the entrance to their school and church facilities.

08 January. A group of bank employees and supporters, called 'Concerned citizens for Justice and against Intimidation', protest against a bank manager who assaulted an employee at Guarantee Trust Bank in Monrovia.

13 January. Three women accused of witchcraft and child kidnapping are led naked through the streets of Johnny Town of Kpanyan in Sinoe County of by an angry crowd of rioters. One woman is killed after rioters sexually assaulted the women with sticks.

20 January. A riot breaks out in Monrovia in front of Ford Maiden Christian Academy on Smythe Road after the bodyguard of Montserrado County District #10 representative, Yekeh Kolubah, bites part of the ear off of a civilian. Rioters throw rocks before the police intervene, disperse the crowd and make 12 arrests.

21 January. Marketers upset over the LMA's lack of trash removal riot in Gobachop Market of Monrovia, dumping rubbish at the LMA office, prevent stores from opening, block streets and demand LMA and PCC remove garbage from the Market area.
21 January. Dozens of Orange cell subscribers protest in front of the Orange office in Monrovia over allegations of hacking.

column7: Students (Liberia); CDC: Coalition for Democratic Change
column17: On 28 January, clashed broke out between SUD and CDC student supporters after SUP students demonstration against the cancellation of classes due to the presidential national address at the Capital Hill University of Liberia in Monrovia city. Several injuries were reported.

31 January. 3 armed men break into the Roots FM radio station in Monrovia by threatening the guards and then destroy the power supply, cutting the broadcast for several hours. The radio station has been critical of the current president George Weah.
31 January. Retirees, upset with the provision of pension payments through NASSCORP rather than the Ministry of Finance, protest in Monrovia outside the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

11 February. Roots FM station in Monrovia is attacked a second time by an unidentified armed group, who stole the transmitter, and took other material. The station held a critical stance towards President Weah, off air.
17 February. Grand Bassa County residents protest in Paynesville outside Monrovia for the resignation of the community forest head, Getrude Karvayan. Police intervene and arrest 2 people with knives.
20 February. Research assistants demonstrate by setting up road blocks in Suakoko of Bong at the Central Agriculture Research Institute demanding higher salaries.
27 February. Rioters throw stones at poll workers in Jallah Town of Monrovia and cause delays to voting, where police intervened to stop the rioters. [size=some]
28 February. A group gathering under the name of Coalition of Islamic Organisation protest in Gbarnga of Jorquelleh against the impeachment of Kabineh Ja'neh. [size=no report]
28 February. Several groups including the Economic Freedom Fighters protest in Monrovia against the impeachment of Kabineh Ja'neh, with reports of some police intervention. [size=mass]

04 March. Sports players from Bomi County Sports Association riot in Kakata after they feel the association failed to pay dues owed to players. Players block traffic and demand payment from vehicles on the Monrovia-Kokata road. [size=no report]

05 March. An unidentified armed group breaks into Joy FM in Monrovia, a critical radio station, damaging equipment and taking the station off of the air. This is part of ongoing attacks on critical radio stations in the country.
11 March. Abi Joudi Supermarket workers in Monrovia riot over wages and benefits by demonstrating in front of the building. [size=no report]
On 20 March 2019, a large group, including moto-taxi drivers, riots in Ganta of Bain and kills two civilians held by police suspected to be involved in ritual killings. [size=10]

23 March. LINSU members protest in Monrovia at GW Gibson High School during a meeting of the Movement for Justice in Africa (MOJA) against the meeting, the MOJA organisation and the speakers chosen for the event. [size=more than 75]

01 April. Motorcycle taxi drivers riot due to the recent death of a colleague by burning the police depots and other buildings in Weala of Kakata. Police arrest over a hundred involved in the demonstration [size=100]
02 April. A labour group from MHM Eko-Liberia protested in Monrovia of Montserrado over unpaid salaries. [size=50]
Early April. A land dispute results in riots between members of Maryland and River Gee County. [size=no report]
25 April. Rioters from Liberty Party and CDC demonstrate in Monrovia at the Capitol Hill, with violence and injuries reported during the riot. [size=hundreds]

23 May. Rubber plantation workers of ARCO rioted setting up road blocks in Todee of Montserrado near the plantation to demand salaries, with police intervening to disperse the demonstration. [size=no report]
Between May 31 and June 3. Two children were abducted in Kingsville and killed by an unidentified armed group in a ritual killing, cutting off their sexual organs and other body parts.

05 June. Student SUP party supporters riot by setting up road blocks at the University of Liberia in Monrovia against the arrest of SUP party chairman, Carlos Edison. Police disperse rioters with tear gas. [size=no report]

05 June. Rioters associated with Independent political party member Yekeh Kolubah throw stones at police forces following Kolubah's arrest at the Liberia National Police headquarters in Monrovia. Police disperse the rioters using tear gas and beat a rioter unconscious. [size=no report]
07 June. COP supporters protested in Tapita, Gbear against poor governance by the CDC. [size=hundreds]

column16: West African Journal; GNN Liberia; Reuters
column17: 07 June. COP protesters demonstrate in Monrovia near Capitol Hill against corruption, poor governance of the country and poor living conditions. [size=thousands]

24 June. Demonstrators blocked the Kakata-Monrovia highway, and threw petrol bombs and stones at police forces in Kingsville, Careysburg after the abduction and ritual killing of two young boys. Police intervened by firing live rounds to disperse the demonstrators. Several demonstrators and police are injured, with one civilian killed. [size=no report]
04 July. Police forces shoot and kill a civilian in Fish Town, Sinoe.

08 July. Protesters demonstrated in front of the Liberia Medicines and Health Products Regulatory Authority (LMHRA) in Monrovia against the current management and sale of expired drugs. [size=no report]
24 July. University of Liberia students protested over delayed faculty salaries in Monrovia near Capitol Hill. Police intervened by forming a human barricade. [size=hundreds]
On 31 July 2019, demonstrators threw stones at police in Monrovia against economic corruption and mismanagement. Police fired tear gas and made arrests to disrupt the demonstrations. [size=100]

On 31 July 2019, Liberty Party and CDC party supporters threw objects at one another over the poor result of a CDC candidate at a recent election, defeated by a Liberty Party candidate. Police intervened by making arrests and firing tear gas. Several were injured in the violence. [size=no report]
04 August. An angry mob attacked civilians suspected to be associated with the murder of a security guard in Red Light area of Paynesville, Monrovia. [size=at least 12]

Between 01 August - 15 August. CDC supporters threw rocks and blocked the entrance to opposition coalition parties, including the Liberty Party, at the Liberty Party building in Brewersville, Mango. Several were injured in the violence. Police intervened to disrupt the CDC members. [size=no report]

column9: ANC: Alternative National Congress; UP: Unity Party
column17: 13 August. CDC party supporters clashed over electoral irregularities with several opposition political party members in Monrovia by throwing projectiles, fist fighting and destroying property. Police intervened to disperse the fighting. [size=no report]

14 August. A street fight broke out between two opposing football teams, who fought against one another following disputes over the football match in Fenplay, Nimba. One died by drowning, unclear if accidental- not coded. Others were wounded and property destroyed following the violence. Police intervened to disperse the fighting. [size=no report]

Week of 14 August. CDC supporters threw rocks at many women who had gathered in support of the coalition of opposition groups, including the Liberty Party, in Logan Town, Monrovia at the Liberty Party headquarters. Several were injured following the violence. [size=no report]

On 17 August 2019, rival political groups fought following local elections in Logan Town, Greater Monrovia. Several injuries and destruction of property reported. Police intervened to disrupt the fighting. [size=no report]

17 August. CDC party supporters demonstrated against an opposition candidate in Monrovia by throwing rocks at her vehicle. The driver was injured before police intervened to disperse the demonstration. [size=no report]

17 August. CDC party supporters demonstrated against a leader of the opposition coalition parties, including Liberty Party. CDC members threw rocks at the opposition leader and others at a meeting in Logan Town, Monrovia. [size=no report]
20 August. ALP and CDC supporters clash in Monrovia over the Montserrado by-elections. Several were injured and some properties were destroyed.  [size=no report]
21 August. Several women's groups demonstrate in Monrovia against ongoing violence against women in the country. [size=no report]
26 August. An unidentified armed group poisoned and raped a woman in Monrovia. The woman had posted a video online critiquing the Monrovia City Mayor of murder and hiding weapons.
02 September. A vigilante group carried out mob justice by killing 3 men accused of witchcraft and murder in Rock Town, Barrobo. [size=no report]
03 September. A group of MHM-Eko workers protested on Capitol Hill in Monrovia against unpaid wages. [size=15]

On September 23, 2019, Rioters, including several expectant and new mothers, erected roadblocks and staged a demonstration in Duport Road to claim the government's attention on Health workers strike demanding the payment of their salaries. [size=no report]

column7: NAHWAL: National Health Workers Association of Liberia
column17: On September 23, 2019, health workers belonging to the NAHWAL: National Health Workers Association of Liberia staged protests demanding the payment of their salaries. [size=hundreds]

column7: NAHWAL: National Health Workers Association of Liberia; Health Workers (Liberia)
column17: On September 24, 2019, hundreds of health workers belonging to the NAHWAL: National Health Workers Association of Liberia staged protests demanding the payment of their salaries. [size=hundreds]

On September 24, 2019, workers of MHM Eko-Liberia protested against the President of the Senate in Monrovia. The accuse him of protecting the Senate Secretary Nanbolor Singbeh in a judicial case where he is sued for unpaid salaries for 15 months. [size=15]

column7: NAHWAL: National Health Workers Association of Liberia; Health Workers (Liberia)
column17: On September 25, 2019, hundreds of health workers belonging to the NAHWAL: National Health Workers Association of Liberia staged protests demanding the payment of their salaries. [size=hundreds]
On October 3, 2019, rioters erected roadblocks and stoned the police at a hospital in Sinkor, demanding the release of a woman who was undergoing treatment. [size=no report]
On October 4, 2019, many Liberians staged a protest in Monrovia, to demand the passage of a rape victim to the US Embassy for a visa appointment. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of Liberia (2018-) Emergency Response Unit
column17: On October 10, 2019, the Liberian Police's Emergency Response Unit intervened and fired teargas at demonstrators in Monrovia as they were demonstrating against the closure of a radio station. Some demonstrators threw stones at the police forces. [size=no report]

On October 15, 2019, Public School Students barricaded a road and threw stones at Police forces which fired tear gas in return in Monrovia, as they were demonstrating to demand that their teachers be paid their salary arrears. The demonstrators then headed to a Private high school where it is believed most government officials have their children, forcing the student to leave the campus and injuring some of them according to some sources (Front Page Africa).

On October 16, 2019, Students of the University of Liberia, Fendell Campus staged a protest to demand the the Early Childhood Pilot Demonstration School's dormitory being available to them. [size=no report]
On October 18, 2019, Students of the University of Liberia protested in Monrovia, demanding the payment of their teachers' salaries. [size=dozens]
On October 28, 2019, violence broke out between students of the FENSA and the SUP on Fendell Campus. The two groups reportedly clashed for supremacy on the Campus. [size=no report]

On October 28, 2019, students of the University of Liberia, demonstrated in Fendell Campus, rejecting the newly appointed President of the University, Dr. Sarwolo Nelson. They forced their colleagues to abandon classes and disrupted normal campus activities. [size=no report]

On October 28, 2019, students of the University of Liberia, demonstrated in Capitol Hill Campus, Monrovia, rejecting the newly appointed President of the University, Dr. Sarwolo Nelson. They forced their colleagues to abandon classes and disrupted normal campus activities. [size=no report]

On October 28, 2019, inhabitants of Kpogbarn [unfound location in Grand Bassa County, coded: Buchanan, capital city of the County] staged a protest against Equatorial Palm Oil Company for its alleged failure to comply with the Concession Agreement. [size=500]

Around October 29, 2019, students of the Nursing Department of the Grand Gedeh County Community College (GGCCC) protested in Zwedru, demanding that full accreditation be granted to the department. [size=no report]

On November 10, 2019, violence broke out during an alleged LGBT party at a HIV treatment centre operated by Population Services International (PSI) in Sinkor (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), after a group of people suspected to be drug addicts threw stones on the participants and reportedly looted money and belongings of the guests. Some injuries were reported and 200 sex workers living with HIV/AIDS fled the compound. PSI later dismissed the LGBT party accusation, saying the party disrupted was a birthday party.

On November 11, 2019, a group of women staged a demonstration in Seclepea, in Nimba County [coded: Sanniquellie, capital city of the county] to demand the burial of a girl whose body is deposited at the Funeral Home since she was reportedly raped and killed in January 2019. [size=no report]

column16: Liberian Observer; New Dawn; Liberia Broadcasting System
column17: On November 14, 2019, workers of ArcelorMittal mining Company erected roadblocks in Grand Bassa County (Buchanan City, Commonwealth) as they were demonstrating in demand of their reinstatement in the company's workforce. [size=no report]

column16: Liberian Observer; New Dawn; Liberia Broadcasting System
column17: On November 14, 2019, workers of ArcelorMittal mining Company erected roadblocks in Nimba County as they were demonstrating in demand of their reinstatement in the company's workforce. [size=no report]
On November 15, 2019, at least 1000 former soldiers of Liberia gathered in Monrovia (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado). The source doesn't report on the reason of their gathering.

On November 18, 2019, students of the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA) School System demonstrated in Kakata (Margibi County), against the administration's failure to provide their uniforms, after collecting money from them. The demonstrators reportedly held the school's principal 'hostage' for more than five hours. [size=no report]

On Novemver 22, 2019, 'scores' of workers of the Liberia Water and Sewer Corporation (LWSC) staged a protest in the city of Monrovia (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), to demand the payment of five months salary arrears and seven months' transportation allowance. They reportedly booed and chanted humiliting slogans against on managing official of the LWSC, Dan Sayeh, who resigned his position some hours later. [size=scores]

column8: Former NPFL: National Patriotic Front Liberia
column17: On 27 November 2019, the police forces arrested an ex-rebel commander in Monrovia (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) after he threatened in a radio speech on 21 November 2019, to create a 'Kru Defense Force' to protect the President.

On 28 November 2019, a group of supporters of the CDC ruling party attacked the members of the SUP party including some leaders, as they were attending the inauguration of the president of the University of Liberia in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado). No fatality and/or casualty reported. [size=no report]

On 1 December 2019, one person drowned in the Mesurado River, in Monrovia's Slipway community (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), as he was attempting to escape the police. This occurred as the police intervened to following violent demonstrations of supporters of one candidate of in the race for the community chairmanship. [size=no report]

On 10 December 2019, in Suakoko (Bong), a group of employees of the Central Agricultural Research Institute (CARI) blocked the offices' entrance and disrupted normal activities, as their were protesting to demand the re-instatement of one of their colleagues who was previously dismissed. [size=no report]

On 11 December 2019, suspected members of Liberian security forces [coded: Police Forces of Liberia] and groups of supporters of the CDC ruling party beat and injured several members of the SUP party including three leaders in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado). The victims were allegedly attacked for being critical against the government.

On 20 December 2019, the police forces clashed with supporters of the COP who gathered to welcome their leader in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) in view of the 30 December planned protests. The confrontation started as the police set up a buffer-zone on Tubman Boulevard to prevent the crowd from entering central Monrovia were their leader was expected to address his supporters. Many people were reportedly injured. [size=100]

column16: Liberian Observer; New Dawn; GNN Liberia; Front Page Africa
column17: On 6 January 2020, supporters of the COP staged a protest in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand that the President improve the country's economy, and dismiss the Minister of Finance and Development. The police forces intervened after some protesters began lighting fire in front of the Capitol Building to cook food for their supporters. The police used tear gas and hot water to disperse them. [size=3000]

On 17 Jan. 2020, a group of women demonstrated before the Capitol in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), against an MP that they accuse of rape. The demonstrators then clashed with a group of young men wearing SUP party T-shirts, prompting the intervention of the police forces. The accused MP dismissed the allegations, say they were politically motivated. [size=no report]

On 23 Jan. 2020, the police forces reportedly attacked a journalist who was covering the National County Sports Meet in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) and damaged his camera and Smartphone.

On 23 Jan. 2020, hundreds of traders and drivers protested in Kakata town, Weamaquelleh/Larkay subdivision (Kakata, Margibi) against the decision of the County Authorities to relocate parking. [size=hundreds]

On 24 Jan. 2020, a group of young men staged a protest in Bardnersville Estate Community of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to denounce the murder of a man who was stabbed to death earlier. Police officers and soldiers calmed protesters, although no physical interaction was reported. [size=no report]

On 28 Jan. 2020, a group of bikers blocked the main streets of Buchanan city (Commonwealth, Grand Bassa) as they were demonstrating against the shortage of fuel (which the authorities denied). [size=no report]

On 6 Feb. 2020 (or around), a group of fishermen protested in Bushrod Island of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) against the high taxes imposed to them by the National Fisheries and Aquaculture Authority (NaFAA). [size=no report]
On 10 Feb. 2020, a group of students burnt a public school in Johnsonville township of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), after they were recently expelled. [size=no report]

On 14 Feb. 2020, former workers of Arcelor Mittal Liberia mining company protested in Bong town, in Hoegbahn subdivision (District No. 3, Grand Bassa) to demand the payment of money owed to them by the company since their dismissal in 2014. [size=no report]

On 14 Feb. 2020, former workers of Arcelor Mittal Liberia mining company protested in Nimba town, in Doe subdivision (Doe, Nimba) to demand the payment of money owed to them by the company since their dismissal in 2014. [size=no report]

On 14 Feb. 2020, former workers of Arcelor Mittal Liberia mining company protested in Grand Bassa town, in Buchanan City subdivision (Commonwealth, Grand Bassa) to demand the payment of money owed to them by the company since their dismissal in 2014. The police forces intervened, beat and injured some demonstrators. [size=no report]

On 21 Feb. 2020, a group of residents of Blouhntuo town in Nimba county reportedly chased out an MP who was visiting. They accused him of not being reachable since he was elected, and of never coming back to the district since then. The MP dismissed that information, saying he left early because of other planned meetings. [size=no report]

column16: New Dawn; Liberian Observer; GNN Liberia
column17: On 21 Feb. 2020 (or around), two military officers attacked a civilian accused of stealing a motorbike in Gbarnga town, Jorquelleh subdivision (Jorquelleh, Bong). The officers were later discharged by the military justice.
On 2 March 2020 (or around), a soldier reportedly arrested and beat one person in Bong, Hoegbahn subdivision (District No. 3, Grand Bassa).

column16: Liberian Observer; Front Page Africa; New Dawn
column17: On 3 March 2020, members of the Liberians United for Justice and Accountability movement demonstrated before the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (temporary office of the President of Liberia) in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to call for the establishment of a War and Economic Crimes Court in Liberia. Police forces and presidential guards intervened, flogged and arrested several demonstrators. Several journalists who were covering the protests were assaulted and arrested. [size=at least several]

On 9 March 2020, a group of rioters blocked the main street and threw stones at the police forces in Ganta town, Bain subdivision (Sanniquellie Mahn, Nimba), as they demonstrated against the killing of a young motorcyclist by a police officer the previous day. The police forces fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. One person was arrested. [size=no report]

On 11 March 2020, scores of journalists demonstrated in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) against repetitive violence against journalists. The police forces intervened to disperse them. They reportedly brutalized several, injuring one demonstrator. [size=scores]

On 30 March 2020, a group of traders demonstrated at the Waterside General Market in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) against authorities demolishing their stalls in the context of coronavirus measures. [size=no report]

column16: 1847 Post; Front Page Africa; AFP; GNN Liberia; Liberian Observer; New Dawn; Xinhua; Liberia Broadcasting System
column17: On 8 April 2020, the government of Liberia declared a 3 week State of Emergency, to combat the coronavirus.

On 10 April 2020, scores of supporters (assumed Christian) demonstrated in Buchanan town (Commonwealth, Grand Bassa) to demand the release of 10 pastors who were arrested for non-compliance with coronavirus measures. [size=scores]
On 11 April 2020, police forces reportedly brutalized residents and damaged their belongings in Tapita, Gbear subdivision (Doe, Nimba), during the enforcement of coronavirus lockdown measures.
On 12 April 2020, the police forces beat up and injured a woman in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), for violating the counter coronavirus curfew.

On 12 April 2020, officers from the army's executive protection service reportedly beaten up and detained several alleged violators of the coronavirus curfew in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado).

On 13 April 2020, dozens of residents attacked and damaged the house of the director of the city's police in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado). They accuse police forces of violence and arbitrary arrests in their enforcement of the coronavirus state of emergency and lockdown measures. They took away households and other belongings. [size=dozens]

As reported on 14 April 2020, a group of unidentified individuals armed with machetes and guns attacked Liberia immigration service (LIS) officers in Gbuyee village, Bain subdivision (Sanniquellie Mahn, Nimba). The assailants were operating an illegal border entry point allowing people to enter and leave the country in violation of the counter coronavirus border closure measure. They attacked the LIS officers who tried to stop their activity. Several of them were arrested. No fatality and/or casualty reported.

As reported on 14 April 2020, members of a police patrol engaged in fistfight with LIS officers in Gbuyee village, Bain subdivision (Sanniquellie Mahn, Nimba) over the control of an illegal border entry point set up by the LIS after the counter coronavirus border closure. One police officer was injured. [size=no report]
On 20 April 2020, a police officer killed a 3 year-old baby while enforcing the anti coronavirus lockdown measure in West Point neighbourhood of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado).

As reported on 21 April 2020, a group of youths beat up a police officer in Taybue town (Kpi, Grand Kru) in reprisal for police violence in the enforcement of coronavirus related measures. [size=no report]
As reported on 21 April 2020, the police forces beat up and injured two suspected violators of anti-coronavirus measures in Taybue town (Kpi, Grand Kru).

On 23 April 2020, the police forces and executive protection service officers captured and tortured a 'mad man' who intruded the residence of the President in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado).

On 26 April 2020, officers of the Liberia drug enforcement agency beat up a pregnant woman and a bike rider in Kakata town, Weamaquelleh/Larkay subdivision (Kakata, Margibi), for violating the counter coronavirus lockdown measures.

column16: Front Page Africa; New Dawn; GNN Liberia
column17: On 28 April 2020, private security guards assigned to the House of Representatives beat up a contractor in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado). This happened after the contractor protested to demand his pay after painting the building.
On 28 April 2020, the police forces beat up a businesswoman in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), because she was not wearing a face mask, as protection against the coronavirus.

On 1 May 2020, residents, mainly women, demonstrated in Tappita town, in Gbear subdivision (Doe, Nimba), to demand the removal of a coronavirus quarantine facility installed in the county. Other sources say that the demonstrators freed quarantined people in the centre. [size=no report]

On 28 May 2020, dozens of Liberians demonstrated at the United States Embassy in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), to show their concern of the killing of a black man by police officers in Minneapolis. [size=dozens]

On 4 June 2020, more than four hundred people armed with firearms and cutlasses entered a mining site after news of the discovery of a gold line in Gboanipea Gold mine, near Tapita town (Doe, Nimba). They outnumbered the private security guards, injuring two people. The police forces were deployed in the area.

On 7 June 2020, two rival groups of the ANC party youth wing clashed with machetes at the party's headquarters in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) over the decision to suspend a party's youth leader. Several injuries were reported. The police forces intervened and arrested one person. [size=no report]

On 9 June 2020, residents demonstrated at the Headquarters of the Liberian National Police in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand justice for a 3-years-old boy who was accidentally killed by a police officer while enforcing the anti coronavirus State of Emergency on 10 April. [size=no report]

On 15 June 2020, hundreds of workers of the Liberia Beaches and Waterways Program demonstrated in front of the Capitol Hill in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), to demand the payment of their 21-month salary arrears. [size=hundreds]
On 20 June 2020, a police officer reportedly beat up and injured a woman in detention in Zwedru town police station (Tchien, Grand Gedeh).

column16: 1847 Post; Liberia Broadcasting System; Front Page Africa; New Dawn; GNN Liberia
column17: On 25 June 2020, supporters of the Council Of Patriots movement demonstrated in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) against GSM companies increasing their tariffs on data. They reportedly burnt tires, caused damage to properties and harassed commuters. The police forces arrested six people in connection with the incident. [size=at least 6]

On 27 June 2020, youths demonstrated in Paynesville neighbourhood of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), after a police officer shot and killed a woman over a private dispute. [size=no report]

On 1 July 2020, a group people demonstrated in front of the Bushrod Island Court in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) the demand the release of a woman who was standing trial on charges of 'criminal coercion and disorderly conduct' after she accused an MP of raping her. [size=no report]

On 1 July 2020, a group of suspected residents of Gbei-Seila, armed with guns and cutlasses, attacked a pastor and his workers in Gbei-Seila town, near Ganta (Sanniquellie Mahn, Nimba) over a land dispute.

Around 7 July 2020, youths demonstrated in Grand Kru County, Barclayville subdivision (Barclayville, Grand Kru) to call for justice following the mysterious death of a teacher on 30 June. [size=no report]

Around 14 July 2020 (as reported), workers of the Mano Manufacturing Company (MANCO) demonstrated in Mano town (Trewor, Grand Cape Mount) to demand salary increments and better working conditions. [size=no report]

On 14 July 2020, workers of the Liberian House of Representatives and Senate demonstrated in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) against what they termed 'unlawful cut to their legitimate salary'. [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (Liberia); CDC: Coalition for Democratic Change
column17: On 20 July 2020, LIBTELCO national telecommunication corporation workers who identified themselves as CDC (ruling) party partisans, demonstrated in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), against what they termed 'bad labour practices' from the LIBTELCO management, and to demand the payment of salary arrears. [size=no report]

On 23 July 2020, an armed gang attacked the residence of a CDC (ruling) party MP in Bushrod Island area of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) reportedly 'demanding gifts' ahead of a planned dedication of a radio station. They clashed with the private guards and threw stones at residents, injuring one. [size=no report]

column9: Military Forces of Liberia (2018-); Civilians (Liberia); ANC: Alternative National Congress; CPP: Collaborating Political Parties
column16: New Dawn; GNN Liberia; Front Page Africa; Liberian Observer
column17: On 30 July 2020, hundreds of youths claiming to be supporters of the CDC (ruling) party attacked two leaders of the ANC (opposition) and CPP (opposition) parties during a visit in Zwedru town (Tchien, Grand Gedeh). They reportedly threw stones at the politicians, demanding that they leave the county. The police forces fired tear gas and shots in the air to disperse the mob. The army was also deployed to settle the situation. [size=hundreds]

column9: ANC: Alternative National Congress; CPP: Collaborating Political Parties
column16: GNN Liberia; Liberian Observer; New Dawn; Front Page Africa
column17: On 30 July 2020, hundreds of youths claiming to be supporters of the CDC (ruling) party attacked two leaders of the ANC (opposition) and CPP (opposition) parties during a visit in Zwedru town (Tchien, Grand Gedeh). They reportedly threw stones at the politicians, demanding that they leave the county. The police forces fired tear gas and shots in the air to disperse the mob. The army was also deployed to settle the situation. [size=hundreds]

On 31 July 2020, students demonstrated in the John Wesley Pearson High school campus in Ganta town (Sanniquellie Mahn, Nimba) to demand the reopening of universities and colleges. One student leader was arrested and shortly detained (assumedly by the Police Forces). [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (Liberia); CDC: Coalition for Democratic Change
column17: On 3 August 2020, LIBTELCO national telecommunication corporation workers who also identified themselves as CDC (ruling) party partisans, demonstrated in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), and to demand the payment of salary arrears, and the dismissal of the LIBTELCO Deputy Managing Director. [size=no report]

On 17 August 2020, students of the University of Liberia and of the African Methodist Episcopal University (AMEU) demonstrated in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) against eLearning and demanding to return to traditional style of education. The police forces intervened to ensure free flow of traffic. [size=no report]

On 18 August 2020, dozens of dismissed workers of ArcelorMittal steel Company demonstrated in Sanniquellie town (Sanniquellie Mahn, Nimba) claiming that the company illegally dismissed them and refused to reinstate them. They blocked the company's railway with coffins, stones and pieces of sticks. [size=dozens]

Around 20 August 2020 (as reported), workers of the Crusaders for Peace entertainment group demonstrated in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand the payment of salary arrears. [size=no report]

On 20 August 2020, residents demonstrated at the headquarters of the Liberia National Police in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), accusing some police officers of requesting money from the parents of rape victims to facilitate the arrest and investigation of perpetrators. [size=no report]

Around 22 August 2020 (weekend of), dozens of demonstrators from two rival groups of motorcycle driver unions demonstrated separately in New Kru Town of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) over the alleged double-standard applied by the Governor in granting official approvals. One group protested against the favouritism in giving parking lot control to the other group, the other group protested to remind the Governor of their agreement. [size=dozens]
On 25 August 2020, hundreds of students demonstrated in Ganta town (Sanniquellie Mahn, Nimba), to demand justice for rape victims in the County. [size=hundreds]

column16: New Dawn; Front Page Africa; Liberia Broadcasting System; Liberian Observer; AFP; GNN Liberia; Executive Mansion
column17: On 25 August 2020, thousands of residents demonstrated in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to denounce increasing cases of rape on young children, and to call on the Government to strengthen the justice system that will allow rape survivors to get justice. The demonstrators threw stones at a CDC party Senator, accusing him of using their movement to earn political gain. Supporters of the Senator replied with stones. [size=thousands]

column16: Front Page Africa; Liberian Observer; Executive Mansion; New Dawn
column17: On 26 August 2020, hundreds of residents demonstrated for the second day in a row, in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to denounce increasing cases of rape on young children, and to call on the Government to strengthen the justice system that will allow rape survivors to get justice. A group of alleged supporters of Monrovia city Mayor on board of 3 cars disrupted the demonstration forcing their way through a blockade set up by the demonstrators in front of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The Mayor denied being associated with that action. [size=hundreds]

Around 28 August 2020 (as reported), dozens of residents demonstrated in Pleebo city (Pleebo/Sodoken, Maryland) to denounce the increasing cases of rape on young children, and to call on the Government to strengthen the justice system that will allow rape survivors to get justice. [size=dozens]

Around 28 August 2020 (as reported), dozens of residents demonstrated in Harper city (Harper, Maryland) to denounce the increasing cases of rape on young children, and to call on the Government to strengthen the justice system that will allow rape survivors to get justice. [size=dozens]
On 31 August 2020, hundreds of residents demonstrated in Picnicess Community of Barclayville town (Barclayville, Grand Kru) against ritualistic killings. [size=hundreds]
On 31 August 2020, residents reportedly flogged three pastors in Parluken village (Barclayville, Grand Kru) for preaching. One of the victims reportedly died of his wounds. [size=no report]
On 4 September 2020, residents demonstrated in Thinkers village of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), to demand justice for a person who died in police custody. [size=no report]
On 5 September 2020, unidentified armed individuals attacked the Liberia Press Union headquarters in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado), taking away electronic equipment.

column7: ALP: All Liberian Party; CPP: Collaborating Political Parties
column9: ANC: Alternative National Congress; CPP: Collaborating Political Parties
column16: Front Page Africa; Liberian Observer; New Dawn
column17: On 6 September 2020, supporters of the ALP and ANC parties clashed during the CPP coalition primary election of Nimba county's senatorial candidate in Sanniquellie town (Sanniquellie Mahn, Nimba). The fight reportedly started as supporters the ALP party candidate attempted to prevent the ANC party candidate and his supporters from accessing the hall where the vote was to be held. At least three people were injured, and a car damaged. [size=at least 3]
On 7 September 2020, coronavirus contact tracers demonstrated in Duport Road Clinic in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand the payment of their wages. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2020, judicial staffs demonstrated in front of the Temple of Justice of Monrovia city (Great Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand the payment of 11-months arrears of the Liberian dollars component of their salaries. [size=no report]

column16: Liberian Observer; Front Page Africa; New Dawn; GNN Liberia
column17: On 13 September 2020, supporters of the CDC (ruling) party clashed with supporters of the CPP (opposition) at a church in St. Paul Bridge Community of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado). The clashes started as supporters of the CDC reportedly attacked a senator for the CPP, resulting in stone throwing from both parts. At least 4 people were arrested in connection with that incident. [size=at least 4]

Around 13 September 2020 (weekend of), supporters of the ANC (opposition) party clashed with supporters of the CDC (ruling) party in two separate locations of Grand Cape Mount County around Robertsport town (Commonwealth, Grand Cape Mount) resulting in at least 3 people severely injured, including a journalist. [size=at least 3]
Around 15 September 2020 (as reported), residents demonstrated in Bahn town, Sanniquellie subdivision (Sanniquellie Mahn, Nimba) to demand electricity connection for their locality. [size=no report]

On 15 September 2020, supporters of two rival candidates running for the senatorial election engaged in fistfight in Tubmanburg town (Senjeh, Bomi) over reports of voters 'trucking' in the county. The police forces intervened and arrested three people. [size=at least 3]
On 16 September 2020, administrative employees of Cuttington University demonstrated in Suakoko town (Suakoko, Bong) to demand the payment of their 8 months salary arrears. [size=no report]
On 16 September 2020, 12 residents captured a woman accused of being a witch and flogged her in Wedabo District, near Barclayville (Barclayville, Grand Kru). [size=12]

On 17 September 2020, administrative employees of Cuttington University demonstrated for the second day in a row, in Suakoko town (Suakoko, Bong) to demand the payment of their 8 months salary arrears. [size=no report]

Around 17 September 2020 (as reported), members of the Association of the Blind demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand their share of the food package for vulnerable people in the context of coronavirus crisis. [size=no report]

On 21 September 2020, members of the Women Rights Platform for Justice demonstrated at the National assembly in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand a halt to a planned confirmation hearing for the Foreign Minister designate pending full investigation into rape allegation surrounding him. [size=no report]

column7: NAHWUL: National Health Workers Union of Liberia; Health Workers (Liberia)
column17: On 23 September 2020, members of the NAHWUL health workers union demonstrated in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand that the US, European Union and United Nations diplomatic missions pressure the Liberian government to address their demands to increase their salaries and recognise them as a union. [size=no report]

column9: ANC: Alternative National Congress; Government of Liberia (2018-)
column17: On 27 September 2020, unidentified individuals armed with machetes, clubs and firearms attacked the house and office of an ANC (opposition) MP in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado). They damaged properties including vehicles, and fled away with valuables. The MP claims the attack was led by a supporter of the CDC (ruling party). No fatality and/or casualty reported.

On 29 September 2020, a group of women demonstrated in front of the Capitol in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand that the House of Representatives amends the National Social Security and Welfare Cooperation Act to address the welfare of Liberians. [size=no report]

On 30 September 2020, legislative staffers demonstrated at the Capitol Building in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand their portion of extra sitting fees distributed to other staffers of the House of Representatives. The riot police intervened to disperse them, beating up several. [size=at least several]

On 30 September 2020, commercial transport bus drivers clashed with bus drivers of the National Transit Authority public transport company in Buchanan Street neighborhood of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado). The confrontation started after some drivers of commercial buses accused their counterparts of the National Transit Authority of stealing passengers that wait on their buses. No fatality and/or casualty reported. [size=no report]
On 5 October 2020, nearly 75 residents demonstrated in Gbarnga town (Jorquelleh, Bong) over mismanagement of the Bong County Development Fund by the leadership of the county. [size=nearly 75]

On 8 October 2020, workers of the Ministry of Justice demonstrated in front of the Temple of Justice of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) after the Minister of Finance and Development Planning failed to attend a planned meeting that aimed at addressing their 11-months unpaid salaries. [size=no report]

Around 9 October 2020 (as reported), a group of 4 people including an ex-military reportedly kidnapped and tortured 27 men in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) over suspicion that they are homosexuals. The perpetrators were arrested. One of the victims was still missing at the moment of their arrest.

column16: Front Page Africa; New Dawn; Liberian Observer
column17: On 12 October 2020, several judicial staffers demonstrated in front of the Temple of Justice of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand the payment of 12-months arrears in the Liberian dollars component of their salaries. The police forces intervened and dragged demonstrators from the premises of the court yard, resulting in 3 people left unconscious. [size=several]
On 14 October 2020, students demonstrated at the Bong County Technical College (BCTC) in Gbarnga town (Jorquelleh, Bong) to demand the dismissal of the university president. [size=no report]

On 19 October 2020, several Catholic school teachers demonstrated in front of the Catholic Education Secretariat in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand the payment of salary arrears. [size=several]

On 19 October 2020, hundreds of market traders, mainly women, demonstrated in Kakata town (Kakata, Margibi) to demand the opening of the local market despite its renovation (that started on May 15, 2019) being incomplete. [size=hundreds]

On 20 October 2020, family members of 3 people who allegedly drowned earlier under unclear circumstances demonstrated in Topoe Community of Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) to demand that the remains of their deceased relatives be found and given to them. [size=no report]

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column16: Liberia Broadcasting System; Front Page Africa
column17: On 21 October 2020, suspected supporters of the UFDG Guinean opposition party demonstrated in front of the Guinean Embassy in Monrovia city (Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) claiming the victory of their party's leader, after the announcement of the partial results of the presidential election according to which incumbent president Alpha Conde was winning the polls. They threw stones at the Embassy and tried to force their way into the buildings. The police forces fired tear gas to disperse them, and arrested several. [size=no report]
Rioters overrun a bank building for unknown reasons. Military forces disperse them.

Libyan police dispersed an anti-regime protest of 500 in the city overnight. 38 injured, one killed. The protest started as a sit-in by families of prisoners killed in a 1996 shooting in Tripolis Abu Salim prison demanding the release of their lawyer Fethi Tarbel.

Four dead in anti-regime ""day of anger"" demonstrations when the group clashed with police, who reportedly used live ammunition to disperse them. Protesters set the local police station and other buildings alight.
Twenty people were killed and at least 38 wounded in the Libyan city of Benghazi in clashes between security forces and anti-regime protesters.
Anti-regime protesters gather in several cities under the banner of a ""day of anger."" Many clashes with police, at least 24 killed throughout the country.
Anti-regime protesters gather in several cities under the banner of a ""day of anger."" Many clashes with police, at least 24 killed throughout the country.
Security forces release a number of prisoners, arm them and pay them to fight protesters.
Violent clashes between rioters and police rocked a city southwest of Tripoli and a number of government buildings were torched. At least two killed.
Anti-regime protesters gather, three killed when police engage them.
Libyan forces storm a protest camp, killing 35. Three others were killed in a separate conflict.
Protesting and rioting continues. Internet access in the city of Tripoli is cut.
Anti-Gaddafi protesters demonstrate with no reported police intervention.
Anti-regime protesters gather. No report of police conflict.
Supporters of Gaddafi begin a counter protest.
Supporters of Gaddafi begin a counter protest.
Anti-Gaddafi protests begin with no police or military intervention.
Supporters of Gaddafi begin a counter protest.
Supporters of Gaddafi begin a counter protest.
Protesters gain control of Benghazi Airport.
Rebels who called themselves ""Islamic Emirate of Barqa"" publicly hanged two loyalist police, 13 others reported killed during clashes. Gaddafi helicopters fired bullets from the air.
Anti-regime demonstrators tear down a statue of Gaddafi in a coastal town.
Over 1,000 prisoners escape during anti-regime protests in Benghazi.
18 are killed when anti-government demonstrators are fired upon by police. 84 have been killed over the past three days throughout the country.
Anti-regime protests spread to Misratah.
Rebel forces win control of a small western city. Remaining forces flee.

column6: Police Forces of Libya (1969-2011) Prison Guards
column17: Security forces shot and killed three convicts when they tried to escape a prison outside Tripoli.
Anti-Gaddafi protesters clash with police. No report of injury.
Anti-Gaddafi protesters clash with police. No report of injury.
Dozens of lawyers join a sit-in outside a Tripoli court, protesting against repression. Many are injured or killed in clashes with security forces, though no numbers are provided.
Police forces flee a city after fighting with rebels and protesters.
A group of armed men attempt to take an army base. One army unit defects and joins rebels. 50+ deaths.

As many as 300 protesters were killed when Libyan security forces and allied mercenaries mowed down mourners with machine guns and anti-aircraft guns at a funeral for anti-government protesters in the eastern city of Benghazi.

Witnesses in Benghazi say Libyan security forces backed by ""African mercenaries"" have been shooting at crowds ""without discrimination."" Dozens killed, many children or other youths. Unsubstantiated reports of ""over 200"" killed in the past week in Benghazi alone.
Libyan forces raid a construction site run by a South Korean firm. Fifteen injured. Workers from Bangladesh were also present.
Explosions at a camp west of Ajdabiya in Libya after bombing by unidentified aircraft. Injuries and deaths not reported.
Anti-government protesters ransack a state television station and set it ablaze.
Military aircraft attacked several different crowds of anti-government protesters in the Libyan capital. Causalities unknown.
Helicopter gunships open aircraft fire on anti-regime protesters, killing many. Specific numbers of causalities not reported. Two Libyan pilots defect and fly to Malta.
Rebels and protesters gain control of several cities and towns following fighting with security forces.
Rebels and protesters gain control of several cities and towns following fighting with security forces.
Rebels and protesters take a city following fighting when police flee.

Several Libyan cities, including Benghazi and Sirte, have fallen to demonstrators opposing Gaddafis rule after army units defected. No report of specific injuries here, however, many believe at least 300-400 demonstrators have been killed since protests began.
Rebels and protesters gain control of several cities and towns following fighting with security forces.
Rebels and protesters gain control of several cities and towns following fighting with security forces.
Sporadic gunfire. Reports of bands of rebels attacking police forces.
Ten Egyptians were shot to death in the Libyan city of Tobruk, near the eastern border. It believed the assailants were border guards.

Several Libyan cities, including Benghazi and Sirte, have fallen to demonstrators opposing Gaddafis rule after army units defected. ""Dozens"" killed here and many believe at least 300-400 demonstrators have been killed since protests began.
State television reports Libyan forces have raided the ""hideouts of the saboteurs"" during the overnight hours.
Libyan forces , armed with aircraft and tanks, fire upon groups of people, killing 26.

More than 1,000 Chinese workers were forced to flee their encampment when it was stormed with gun wielding anti-regime demonstrators. Though there were no deaths reported in this instance, there are some reports that 62 had died in the city since Sunday.

A Libyan student who saw his friends killed in protests against the rule of Muammar Gaddafi in the town of Al Bayda said on Tuesday that mercenaries from Africa had killed dozens on the Libyan leaders orders.Gaddafi used tanks, helicopters and warplanes to fight a growing revolt, witnesses said on Tuesday, as the veteran leader scoffed at reports he was fleeing after four decades in power. Rebel soldiers said the east of Libya had broken free from the leaders control.Saddam, a 21-year-old student who declined to give his full name, told Reuters that mercenaries from Chad, Tunisia and Morocco had opened fire on protesters.
A band of protesters set fire to several government buildings, clash with government forces. ""Dozens killed"".

Change to armed group: Several soldiers defect and join demonstrators. Rebel forces now control most of Libyas east. A total of 104 civilians and 10 soldiers have been killed in Benghazi since demonstrations began.
Helicopter gunships and aircraft fire upon anti-regime protesters, killing 600 allegedly. This number may be less. Hundreds more wounded. Reports of soldiers randomly firing on people.
A Swedish national is shot and killed while in his home.
Army units attack a mosque sheltering protesters and other civilians in a small town 40km west of Tripoli. Causalities not reported.
6,000 Turkish nationals flee Libya. One killed in the fighting.
Five are killed when security forces open fire on protesters in a Tripoli suburb.
Security forces fire upon demonstrators, and eventually break up the crowd. ""Several"" people killed.
Libyan forces loose control of Ziltan, causalities not reported.
A Somali citizen is killed during unrest.

Hundreds of demonstrators gathered in the eastern Libyan port city of Tobruk on Wednesday to continue protest against the leadership of embattled premier Muammar Gaddafi. Later in the day the demonstrators clash with police and gain control of the city.

Rebel forces battle security forces for control of Mosque, eventually becoming a victor. 17 deaths reported, 150 wounded. Rebel forces are in control of the majority of the city. Sore reports have the deaths higher.
A group loyal to the Gaddafi regime hold a protest, denouncing the uprising.
Police and soldiers flee the remaining districts of a city after an attack in an effort to retake the city. 23 killed, dozens wounded.
Residents of a southeastern desert town overthrow security forces.
A group of Thai workers are looted of their belongings by anti-regime protesters.
Heavy gunfire breaks out by security forces as they were inspired to fight following a speech by Gaddafi. Many districts of the city are inundated by loyalist forces.
Italian journalists are manhandled by authorities upon their arrival in Tripoli.
Anti-regime protests renew in Zuwarah.
Rebel gain control two major oil ports with access to the Mediterranean. The precise date of the takeover is conflicted.
Gaddafi forces open fire on protesters gathered in the Tajoura District to denounce them. Causalities not reported.
Four civilians are killed when government forces fire their weapons from rooftops in Tripolis Souq al-Jomaa district.
Protesters revolt over a government shutdown of media and cellular communication. 12 captured mercenaries are being held by rebel forces and a group of rioters.
Change to armed group: A large number of security forces defect and join protesters.

""Tens"" killed during fighting around the city. Gaddafi forces indiscriminately open fire on civilians who were leaving a mosque after morning prayers. Tanks and checkpoints are established by government forces in many thoroughfares.
An armed anti-Gaddafi group takes control an airport east of Tripoli.
Three Somali nationals are killed by anti-regime protesters,
Protesters demanding the ousting of Gaddafi are fired upon by government forces. Casualties unknown.
Government forces attempt to take an airbase in control by rebels. Outcome and causalities unknown.
Change to armed group: A large number of security forces defect and join protesters.
Security forces open fire on rebel forces and protesters who already control the city. No causalities reported.
Gaddafi forces, armed with tanks, retake an Air Base from rebel forces. At least 30 killed.
Gaddafi forces and mercenaries attempt to take an airport outside Misratah controlled by rebels. Efforts fail when many forces defect and hand their weapons to rebels.
Armed bands of pro-Gaddafi supporters patrol the streets of Tripoli looking for defectors and securing areas.
Rebel forces repel government forces who flee across the border to Tunisia. Many members of Gaddafis defect, run to opposition forces side.
Security forces abandon a district of the city of Tripoli. Protesters have erected barricades of rocks and palm trees across rubbish-strewn streets.
Five dead when security forces open fire on protesters who were near a Mosque.
Rebel forces capture several towns in the west. Causalities and exact dates not reported.
Rebel forces capture several towns in the west. Causalities and exact dates not reported.
Rebel forces capture several towns in the west. Causalities and exact dates not reported.
Rebel forces capture several towns in the west. Causalities and exact dates not reported.
Rebel forces capture several towns in the west. Causalities and exact dates not reported.
Rebel forces capture several towns in the west. Causalities and exact dates not reported.
Rebel forces capture several towns in the west. Causalities and exact dates not reported.
Rebel forces capture several towns in the west. Causalities not reported. This city hold the countries largest oil refinery.
Misratah city and its airport are in complete control of rebels/protesters following a battle over many days. Causalities unclear.

Protesters gather in a Tripoli neighborhood to denounce the Gaddafi regime. Security forces open fire into the air and bullets fell upon the crowd, came at them with tanks, and they were quickly dispersed. One report states 17 were killed.
Two killed and one wounded when security forces open fire on a group of passersby.
Protesters gather to denounce Gaddafi. One individual throws himself into a grave to demonstrate he is willing to die for his beliefs.
Rebel forces repel a government effort to take back a captured city. Casualties inflicted, however, numbers are not provided.

column6: Operation Unified Protector: NATO Mission in Libya (2011-2011)
column7: Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
column17: Throughout the month of March the US Air Force, with the cooperation of NATO, used B-52s and B1Bs to attack targets throughout Libya, before the NATO ally officially became entangled in the Civil War.
Gaddafi forces attempt to take Zlitan from opposition forces, but are unsuccessful. No report of causalities.
Gaddafi forces attempt to take Gharyan from opposition forces, but are unsuccessful. No report of causalities.
Twelve fighters are killed during a fight with security forces in a port city. Rebel forces are eventually able to repel their attackers.
A British civilian is shot and killed when Gaddafi forces launch an attack.
Arrests: Three Dutch Marines are captured by Gaddafi forces when their helicopter crashes as they attempted to evacuate civilians from Sirte.
Recruitment: Eight hundred Tuareg originating from Mali, Algeria and Burkina Faso have been recruited by Libya to fight on Kadhafis side,"" a Malian security source told AFP.
Two Red Cross ambulances came under fire by an unknown group.
Libyan warplane bombs the rebel town of Brega, two days after a land battle had claimed they lives of twelve. Witnesses report no causalities.
Reports of loyalist forces carrying out a series of pre-emptive raid on the homes of civilians around the capital. Dates of raids conflicting.
Ariel bombing target a rebel-held ammunition depot in the outskirts of a city. No reported injuries.
Four killed in an aerial bombardment by Gaddafi forces.
Rebel forces report they have captured 100 of Gaddafis forces during fighting in Brega.
Many people in Benghazi, a town solidly in rebel control, hold a protest against the regime while waving old Libyan flags.

Rebel forces, armed with shoulder fired anti-aircraft weapons, set up a series of checkpoints leading to the headquarters of the Sirte Oil Company, as they believe it will be a strategic target for Gaddafis forces.
At least eight people were killed and 20 wounded Friday during heavy clashes between loyalists and eastern rebels near an oil compound. Rebels claims to control Ras Lanuf following the clash.
An explosion at a rebel weapons depot kills 19. Many suspect sabotage by Gaddafi forces.
Protesters gather at Green Square in the center of the city to denounce Gaddafi. The group is quickly dispersed by security forces and tear gas.
Protesters gather following Friday prayers, chanting ""Gaddafi is the enemy of God!"" Government forces move in and disperse them with tear gas.

Protesters gather outside Murad Agha mosque after noon prayers to denounce Gaddafi. Security forces fire teargas to disperse them and other weapons to disperse them. The protesters numbered more than 400. 37 reported dead.
Fighters loyal to Gaddafi set up checkpoints in Tripoli, searching cars, ahead of planned anti-government protests.
Pro and anti Gaddafi supporters fight each other in a Tripoli street.
Intense fighting reported in Bin Jawwad.
Gaddafi forces launch a new bid for the city Zawifa. At least eighteen dead. Rebels are eventually able to repel them.
Gaddafi forces launch a second air strike in as many days on an ammunition depot rebels hold. No reported injury or death.
Sporadic gunfire reported around the city centre known as ""Green Square.""
Rebel forces shoot down a Gaddafi jet with an anti-aircraft battery, killing the two pilots.
Rebel forces shoot down a Gaddafi helicopter, killing the pilot(s).

Gaddafi forces launch a another wave of assaults on a rebel held town. At least 60 confirmed dead +causalities and missing. This site is particularly valuable as it is home to a major oil refinery and ammunitions depot. Rebels are able to hold the town after two days of fighting.
Government forces are met with strong resistance when they try to take a town controlled rebels. Most of the fighting occurred in the outskirts of town. Causalities not reported.

A Gaddafi warplane struck a rebel hold oil town causing two craters, but no other damage or injury. This strike was an apparent attempt to damage the refinery. The explosions caused a retaliation of anti-aircraft fire.

Government forces reclaim the control of a town after two days of fighting. 31 tanks were lost by rebels. No report of causalities, though it was reported that 30 civilians were killed when tanks targeted apartment buildings.
Four Al Jazeera journalists are kidnapped by Gaddafi forces. A cameraman was released in mid April and fled to Tunisia.
Forces loyal to Gaddafi have recaptured the town of Tobruk far into the formerly rebel-held east and close to the Egyptian border. Causalities not reported.
Gaddafi tanks shelled Misratah near the city centre. At least 18 dead.
Clashes break out in a coastal town, killing 30, wounding others, including a French journalist.

Tribesmen from the Tuareg community of Africas northwestern country of Mali have joined the forces supporting embattled Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi, a media report said. A large number of men from the ethnic group left Mali last week to join pro-Gaddafi forces in Libya, an unnamed official told BBC in Mali.
Airstrikes targets rebel held areas. No causality list.
Airstrikes target rebel held areas. 12 killed causing much of the rebel force to loose ground.
18 killed in fighting.

An airstrike targets rebel held areas, kills 12 and wounds a father and his son. Rebels loose their footing and government forces regain portions of the town. Reports of Gaddafis forces intentionally targeting civilians.
Twelve killed and 50 injured after a series of clashes between rebel and loyalist forces.
Airstrikes targets rebel held areas. 21 killed, 91 in the shelling, including at least one civilian.
Report of heavy fighting in Misratah. 21 dead plus 100 wounded.
Government forces retake a city. No word of causalities.
A group of Army officers are rounded up and executed for refusing to tell their men to fire on protesters. Numbers unclear.
Government forces claim they have retaken an area of the city.
Artillery shells from government forces cause massive explosions at an oil facility. No report of causalities. After a short advance rebel forces retreated back to previous positions within the city.
Heavy shelling by government forces reported, rebels respond with 40 Katyusha rockets launched from mobile units. Gaddafi forces eventually take the city after much fighting.

Government forces claim to have completely retaken at city once held by rebel forces. Heavy artillery has destroyed much of the infrastructure, including residential buildings and mosques. Some reports have rebel forces maintaining the city.
Three BBC journalists are detained and beaten while covering fighting.,

Government forces move closer to a rebel held town following a series of airstrikes five miles to the east of the city, striking rebel positions in the desert. By days end government forces had taken the majority of the city. Government artillery and airstrikes hit residential houses.
""Two national Red Crescent medics were injured by a ricochet of bullets that hit a wall while they were trying to clear a corpse.""
An oil pipeline terminal held by rebel forces suffers a direct hit by government forces.

Libyan rebels battled troops loyal to Gaddafi outside Ras Lanuf finding themselves on the back foot and outgunned a day after the regime recaptured the key oil town. Many airstrikes reported outside the city. Four reported killed, plus injuries.
Reports of fighting between rebel and government forces.
Security Measures: Police force erect roadblocks and barricades to prevent expected demonstrations following Friday prayers in two Tripoli neighborhoods.
Security Measures: Police force erect roadblocks and barricades to prevent expected demonstrations following Friday prayers in two Tripoli neighborhoods.
Government forces launch an airstrike on two road checkpoints near a costal town held by rebels. No word of causalities.
Thousands of women demonstrate in favor of implementing a no fly zone over Libya.
An Al Jazeera journalist is shot and killed while coving fighting in the rebel stronghold of Benghazi.
Pro-Gaddafi forces take the town of Bishr on the way to Brega.
Rebel forces retreat from a costal town following a bombardment by from Gaddafi forces.
Waves of arbitrary arrests and forced disappearances reported around Tripoli.
Government forces attack pockets of resistance in a western town, tighten their grip on the city.
Heavy artillery fire is heard above Benghazi as Gaddafi forces move closer after the retaking of Ajdabiya. No report of injury.

Explosions and anti-aircraft fire rocked the western edge of rebel-held Ajdabiya as Libyan Gaddafis forces pressed their attacks on the key town. Ajdabiya is the next logical town for government forces to take before reaching Benghazi. One dead from an airstrike, others from combat.
A large number of Ajdabiyas 140,000 residences flee toward Benghazi when their city is attacked by Gaddafi forces.
Eleven reported dead, 20 wounded due to fighting in Misratah.
Gaddafi forces attack a western town with heavy artillery. Causality list not yet reported.
Gaddafi forces take the area in and around the south gate of Ajdabiya.
Loud anti aircraft explosions as Benghazi is shelled by loyalist forces.

Rebel fighters began attacking government positions near a western mountain town. One rebel fighter was reported killed, and four pro-Gaddafi fighters were claimed to have been killed, along with 18 captured.
Gaddafi forces shell cities with artillery fire. No report of injury or death.
Rebel aircraft bomb oil piplines used by Gaddafi forces.
A series of airstrikes are reported southwest of Benghazi launched by Gaddafi forces.
Gaddafi forces launch strikes on Tripolis rebel forces. Civilians reportedly hurt.
Rebel forces are able to shoot down a Gaddafi MiG over Benghazi.

column6: Operation Unified Protector: NATO Mission in Libya (2011-2011)
column17: French air forces attack an air defense site east of Tripoli.
Gaddafi forces claim they have downed a French aircraft in the Njela section of the city.

column6: Operation Unified Protector: NATO Mission in Libya (2011-2011)
column17: French aircraft destroy several Gaddafi tank positions south-west of Benghazi.
Rebel forces and civilians experience a sustained shelling of Benghazi as well as a series of airstrikes from Gaddafi forces.
Gaddafi forces shell cities with artillery fire. No report of injury or death.
Gaddafi forces launch artillery fire into Misratah and cut off nearly all supply routes leading out of the city.
